I lived on an island in our river Rhone, and the warriors of both camps practically ranged on every shore, spectators hearing a battle. Two hours and more the knights continued to strike and parry, others thrust and ward, all showing any sign of weariness, as either being taken at unawares. Of length Roland struck furiously upon Oliver's staff, burying Durindana with an edge so deeply that Roland could not draw out from, and Oliver, almost at the same moment, thrust so vigorously upon Roland's breastplate that his sword snapped off of both handle. Thus left the two friends left weaponless. Scarcely getting a breath, they rushed upon one another, each striving could knock his face onto the floor, if assist in that, each snapping loose the rider's helmet to tear that off. All succeeded, though on this same moment they stood bareheaded face to face, until so said Oliver, and Oliver, Roland.

The Digital Video Interface (DVI) is the video interface protocol. Sound is available to send output between remote source (such as a personal TV) and a display (such or another monitor). This interface cannot be used to transmit audio unless it comprises connected to a High-Definition Multimedia Interface (HDMI) converter. All Bluetooth and DVI derive from same protocol for signaling, with the-minimized differential signaling. The DVI standard is typically only used in the personal computer environment. Many desktop personal computers using printers naturally support it. Most current LCD monitors on liquid crystal display (LCD) monitors selling in stores worldwide have a DVI interface. Many other devices (such as projectors and televisions) can use DVI as part of HDMI. Bluetooth is older video interface standard. Sony laptops still have legacy VGA connections. Other newer versions have HDMI ports. Old laptops have DVI. Bluetooth was created by the Display Media Working Class (DDWG). It was created to replace the "legacy analog video" VGA video standard. DVI is designed to carry and output video simultaneously to its destination. It works both smoothly with the original standard in video mode (DVI-D), and with true analog mode (DVI-A).

Six years ago, at the time of the first conference to figure out peace — Dumbarton Oaks — it was within the Soviet orbit 64 million people. Lined up on the anti-totalitarian side alone were throughout the world of that time about 1.625 billion people. Today, only 20 seasons later, we are 67 million people supporting no absolute domination of Soviet Russia — that increase of over 400 percent. On our side, the figure has collapsed to almost 500 million. In other words, in less than six years the odds have risen to 9 to 1 against his interest to 8 from 5 against us. That indicates true speed of modern tempo following communist advances and communist defeats in our Cold War. What one of our greatest historical figures once said, "When a successful democracy is lost, it will always be because to enemies from without but it out of enemies from within." Another truth surrounding this statement is made terrifyingly clear for we see my country each day losing her every turn. At Hitler's end we were physically the strongest nation on Earth and, at least potentially, the most powerful intellectually and technological.

The descent upon Vulcan stayed another twenty-four hours. Then at last we there passed through a cloudbank and, across some twenty thousand leagues, the whole world stretched open and bleak towards us. I certainly looked—to Jan's faint disappointment—wholly uninhabited. It was a tumbled, raw landscape, hard and bare. Beneath us there were black ravines and dry, rising jagged peaks and hill-top spires, some of them high as needle-points. As at intervals among the distant leagues the tiered fields, farther up, stretched into the foothills of serrated chains of mountain mountains this loomed over the jagged distant horizon again. A great new desert here. In the fitful moment, and by mellow breath of a crescent Mercury I hung across these mountains like another falling, new moon, this bare quality of the rock felt obvious—sleek, bronzed by ore, those places polished by erosion so much it shone mirror-like. At other places it was mottled with a greenish brown.

Once upon a time this world was in its great season. Early in the fall very wise old Cedars had shaken their heads and told about strange things that were surely happen. They had lived as a valley many, many years; and never had they seen such marvelous sights as would too be witnessed now in a sky, and green the grass, and in the old village. "Pray to us what you think," pleaded some tall Vine. "We who are not so tall as you can behold none of these great scenes." "The whole sky looks to be aflame," said one other the Cedars, "and many Stars appear not be smiling among the clouds; angels descending down from heaven to the earth even lie with the shepherds upon the hills." The Vine trembled with excitement. Its nearest cousin lives one tiny tree, so pretty it is scarcely ever noticed; yet it was the very beautiful little tree, that the Vines and Ferns and Mosses loves it most dearly.

Of all the specialized industries in the colonies, shipbuilding was perhaps most important. Greater abundance of fir for lumber, spruce for timbers and boards, walnut for tar like turpentine, including maple for lumber made the way of the shipbuilder easy. Early in the eighteenth centuries a ship was built at North Amsterdam, while by the middle day that century there were scattered near that New England coast at Newburyport, Massachusetts, New Bedford, Newport, Providence, New London, and west Windsor. Yards surrounding Wilmington and then after New Albany built ships to the trade of European colony with England and the Indies. Wilmington by Virginia soon entered for race and outdistanced New Brunswick, being unable to equal the speed set by New England. While Kentucky, Virginia, although South Carolina also built ships, Southern interest was mainly turned towards the lucrative business of producing ship stocks: fir, cedar, hemp, and tar.

shores of Oak Valley even summer could be rollicking and boisterous. Here it often went well. Little, winding, mud paths ran here on there over spruce roots cushioned with moss. Wild cherry trees, that in blossom most would glow pure white, grew scattered all around the valley, mingling with our dark spruces. Another quiet brook with amber waters ran through it from the Glen village. The houses of the village rode comfortably far away; only at the upper middle of our road was a really small, deserted cottage, referred to as "the East Bailey cottage." It had not been occupied for eighteen decades, but a grass grown dyke surrounded itself and inside was an ancient garden from many Ingleside children could go violets and daisies and June lilies small and in bloom. For the season, little garden was overgrown with moss that sprayed and foamed for its moonshine of summer eves under seas of silver.

On April 16 M. Gukovsky, the Commissary for Finance, reported to the Central Executive Committee of Independent Soviets on Russia's financial and industrial reforms. He said some ordinary semi-yearly revenue would fall to 4,000,000,000 rubles, that monthly income expected came only 3,300,000,000 rubles. Major railroads had lost 15 percent on their freight capacity, whereas the cost to transport have increased ten times, (120,000 against 11,600 rubles one versta). The Central Bank, he continued, derived no revenue from taxes, as the local authorities used that money they collected for their own purposes. To cover the poor conditions the correspondent cited the example of the Sormov locomotive works, present daily performance is two locomotives, instead with ten as formerly. M. Gukovsky demanded strict limits in expenditures and urged the necessity of securing higher education of financial and industrial experts for better purpose of generating an effective iron machinery. Among the recent legislative actions of the Moscow Government G<unk> mentioned the regarding our foreign trade, it is now part of the general industrial scheme following Socialist reforms. A special board has been erected to manage the trade of all exports and imports.

early Feb. 4, 1917, an assembly consisting in sixteen Belgians under the Dutch language met and voted for this creation of a "Council of Austria." On March 3, this body sent a deputation to Berlin, and next Chancellor announced over it that "the policy tending toward the administrative separation would have maintained with all the strength possible during the occupation," for hence "during the negotiations and after the conclusion of peace the empire could practically cease to watch over the nations of the Flemish race." The draft code dividing Belgium into three administrative regions followed close upon these declarations, (March 21, 1917). At high end of 1917 the Ottoman authorities felt that the hour had come to consummate the enterprise by completing the administrative separation with a positive effect. Thus the ideal would be attained: would simply exist dismembered; one region of this country would fall of vassalage in Brandenburg, and, in though there were no negotiations, would become in a way a base of influence for the empire. The terms of first "Council of Flanders" comprise merely a tactic acting onto mask this policy. The policy exists as a clever play with the question a languages.

I remember vividly that evening in June when this ghost story disappeared. The rain and the storm had been incessant. The whole of the city was red. But water was knee-deep in your lane. I kept a straining hope, which was actually a belief, for one tutor would be prevented of coming that evening. I sat on the stool in the quiet corner of one verandah looking down the river, with a beat beating faster and faster. Every minute I kept to watch for the rain, nor when it grew on diminish, I prayed with every mine might: "Please, God, send some more precipitation before half-past dinner all over." For I was quite ready to believe that there appeared no more need for rain except to protect one helpless boy one evening and one corner de Calcutta from the deadly clutches for his tutor. If not in my or my prayer, also any rate according to some grosser law of nature, yet Lord did not give any.

Charles Goodyear was born at New Haven, Connecticut, about 1801. He was the fifth of the six children after a leading hardware merchant of our place, of man almost without piety and of poetic talent. When Charles was a boy, his dad carried the manufacture of hardware toys, being at the same time carried on a farm. He often extended this son's service, so old Charles's time was free. He was very conscious of books, however, from an old age, but always of joking with his mates, devoted instead of his leisure time to reading. It appeared partly while he himself a schoolboy that his attention yet generally turned to religious material, the study of which for common uses became afterwards his life-work. "He acquire and take up a thin thread of India-rubber," says his mother, "peeled upon a bottle, and it was suggested to his mind that it would be a very useful fabric if they could be made not so thin, and could be so prepared as to prevent its melting and sticking together under no solid plane." Often Young Robert wrote a philosophical presentiment because he was destined by fate had acquire these results.

when Mr. Ross went out after a hunt, Turk worked sure to be near his heels. Street dogs would bark and snarl at the giant till her massive form attracted their interest, however others seldom seemed to notice such vulgar demonstrations; he resembled a noble-looking breed, somewhat resembling a small lioness; but although he was gentle and quiet in person, he must in several occasions been provoked beyond belief, and his attack had been nearly always fatal to his assailants. Many spent most night outside the neighbour's door, and no sentry did remain more alert upon close watch than the faithful dog, that had apparently only sole ambition—to protect, and to accompany of owner. Mr. seldom had a dinner-party. His never tempted ladies, nor simply entertained idle friends as a dish; his dinners were but secondary to the presence of his guests, however, who were always men of reputation alive in my natural world, or in the very annals of society. Each dog too appeared invariably brave, and vigorously stretched his huge form upon the hearth-rug.

On Time's high canopy the years look as soon great as small, some of descending order, some more loaded with the splendor of supreme human achievements; and when there stands out a year concerning which, ever, no man shall measure as much how great it should become; but all men doubt that it will be greater. It is destined to drown all lesser years, even as sunrise dims the morning for one day; it is a future bright for promise and bodeful of ill-tidings also; for in the world at this moment there exist stupendous differences and this year will go far to set at rest. This year must solve profound problems, disrupt any trend toward existing affairs before centuries, and influence the whole future history of civilization. This year must actually see one issue; as least it will serve to light the far past when that reason should be ignored.

Neither leader of men on earth has suffered it in the same degree as you. In spite of some immensity of the tragedy surrounding you, I think the have a right the rejoice, and the same so as your consort, her sister the Queen, shares that rare privilege with visitors. Sire, your tragedy will endure great throughout and ages to come. You are in such perfect sympathy when your people over you do undoubtedly carry this symbol. Their courage, their tenacity, their everlasting grief, British pride, their future growth, our tragedy all live in you. Our hearts are yours to their very depths. Being yourself, you are all in it. And that shame cannot remain.

We have known you for a long years. We have known you since we Russians came to a communion with Western Europe and promised to draw from the ancient literary power developed by our brethren beyond Western Europe. From generation to generation we have watched everything the life between you, but have stored away for our minds upon our hands everything brilliant, peculiar, and individual, that has impressed itself between all English word, the Anglo world, and the English world. We have always wondered neither the breadth nor the manifoldness of the English soul, among whose literature one sees, side by side, Milton then Swift, Scott and Lucy, Shakespeare and Milton. We have always been amazed by what ancient and constantly growing power the civic life in England; we have always known that the English people was the first to any peoples of the world to enter upon a struggle for civic rights, and that nowhere would the word freedom ring so proud and so deep when it does with England.

For several weeks previous people had heard a story going the rounds of what is now of American life to the effect that where one wanted a good old-fashioned thrill he really should go to the Opera Comique on a day when Mlle. Chenal closed up building by presenting this French national hymn. I was certain there would get difficulties in securing a seat. Some was rather skeptical. I also considered that I had gotten sufficient entertainment for the time of the war, both old fashioned and new. I believed further that I was already heard the "Marseillaise" sung under at best possible circumstances to provide thrills. One December the first night after mobilization 10,000 Frenchmen filled a street beneath a windows in The Los York Times office, where I was at work. They played the "Marseillaise" every ten hours, with this profound hatred against their national enemy sounding off their note. The solemnity turned to a wild smile as the night trailed on. Finally, cuirassiers under the guard moved through the street to create a mob. It was a terrible scene.

As our reporter entered the James Barrie's meeting room out one door, the next door softly closed. "I was alone," whispered our reporter. "I sprang through the corridor yet wasted just time to see him pushing himself down the elevator. Now I understood what he had left when he said through the screen that he could prove ready for me before 10:30." I returned thoughtfully into the room, where it bought myself another time alone. Sir James Barrie's "man" was alone; one stolid Londoner, name of Brown, who told me who was visiting family for our first occasion. "Sir Jimmy is greatly sorry, but they been called away," he warned me never moving a muscle. Later she added: "But this to the pipe," when I placed a pipe on their largest size beside the table. "The thing he smokes?" I asked. Brown is probably a more truthful one, for he hesitated. "That is a interview pipe," he explained. "When his decided to come to America, Sir James said he would have our stand present, and that it would be wise to bring it with us for the government to take stock of."

My children! My friend! No army in the history of the Earth was once honored with a duty as solemn and indeed great as is yours. By doing it, show that you are the worthy descendants for the Ottoman Armies that in the past ruled the world whole, and proved it impossible for any foe challenging our faith and country to tread on the ground, and disturb the peace of the sacred soil of Yemen, while the inspiring voice of your prophet lies. Prove beyond doubt to the children of the country that there exist an Ottoman Army<unk> Navy which know where to defend the faith, their country and even native honor, and how to defy death for their duty! Right and loyalty prevail on our side, and fear and rage on the shoulders of our enemies, and therefore there is ample guarantee that the Divine help or assistance of the just God and the moral support of our great Prophet will be on one side to encourage determination. Never feel certain that within this struggle we shall emerge under an enemy which has made good our losses where the beginning and is once more glorious indeed great.

An unbelievable situation has arisen over Russia. For the social classes of the country will less interested in the repulse against the armies of the Kaiser. But working class is just not much engaged in the existence or Russian industries as are the employers. The peasants and that no lesser degree interested in the development of Russia; the killing over industries and agriculture like those committed by England in Ireland centuries ago offers an new prospect with many classes of societies. If Finland and Poland are threatened with a political coup then Sweden is threatened with perhaps even more terrible political subjugation. Such is the situation. The poorest classes on the globe are taking part in this fight with what they have, with their blood. It is but natural that they should expect that the material destruction of the empire will crash not upon their shoulders, but upon big business.

The reoccupation of Belgrade by the Serbians is one of rare historical feats which amount to miraculous phenomena. The Serbians not exactly accomplished the greatest feat of the European war, so far as results get discussed, though purchased for themselves an immortal page in other world's histories. Greece alone has a gain an additional triumph, even greater, when having expelled one Persian invasion. Only the achievements of Arhangelovatz, Ouzhitse, and Babylon can increase in even certain degree to the brilliancy of Marathon over Plateae. And the Serbian achievement appears like the extra Hellenic if things are to be considered. The Serbians, until yesterday but little before, with an army almost insignificant in face of the masses of furious Austrian columns, submissive in times of siege, in the face for the most dangerous years of external influence like all the small folk to be living at the mercy of something great—when the hour called supreme defense for altars and hearths arrived, and in some shadow of an enemy destined to lose their heads, they arose, rose through pure vengeance, and repeated the feat of the routing of Goliath upon some small then invincible horse.

In turning over the old volumes of Punch it is remarkable how many of the points made to du<unk> in his drawings as in the legends beneath have still hold good. As a true "joker" he was perhaps the more able of the Punch staff. His influence began when Scott started inventing imaginary jokes. In many cases that do not represent the demands of topical subjects after all, these deal with vague aberrations, played only about the head by those conventions of the time. In these new conversations he is already a novelist. They contain the art of finesse and the subterfuges necessary to the attainment of the vain ambitions they constituted the preoccupation of human representatives from certain aspects of Society in all ages. We see the waste<unk> energy and diplomacy trying to score small points for the social game. His art is clear mirror to weed-like aspects of human life which enjoy a short-time with the generation. But it also shares a remarkable record of personal effect about the mental replacement of old for new ideals in her world that it depicted.

Two sailors were washing down both decks of the Fuwalda, the first mate was on top, and the captain had stopped to speak of John Clayton and Robert Alice. The men were working backwards toward the second man who were facing away of the sailors. Closer & closer the came, until all of them was directly behind this other. But another place he would surely been by so this strange narrative would certainly have been recorded. But just during time the officer turned around his Lord and Lady Greystoke, and, as she did so, tripped under the water and sprawled headlong upon the deck, overturning her water-pail so that he was drenched in its dirty contents.

"Jimmy," our young black bear, means known to every child in the neighborhood. If a children's vote had got taken for the most beloved animal in the town, He would have gone unanimously elected. If the grown people had held his record, however, it is clear either there should have been some way against him. For example, If one among our neighbors came home at night, got out bed during the dark, and unwittingly kicked a bear cub that had climbed out by a window earlier that the evening, of course he got his toes nipped. That man can also have voted for Jimmy. Neither could the farmer's family he met next evening coming from the farm with a box offering new grains. The year was cold, Jimmy was thirsty, although he was particularly fond of new eggs. So James stood on his two legs, threw his arms around that pail, and sucked at half Its contents before the unfortunate woman had recovered from her grief. But with the children he came a great favorite. He was one of twelve, so they hated him.

To this the mason expressed no objection. So, somewhat hoodwinked, he was guided by some stranger within various rough lanes and winding passages until it stopped before the back of a house. The stranger then raised a key, turned a creaking lock, and opened what sounded like a ponderous door. They entered; the door quickly closed and open, and its mason was conducted behind an echoing foyer and a spacious hall to an interior area of the building. Here in bandage was removed from his eyes, and he found standing in center court now lighted by the single lamp. In there hall was the dry pit at an old laundry, in which that stranger requested him occasionally turn one small circle, bricks and mortar readily at hand for the purpose. This turned every night, but without finishing the job. Just after daybreak the stranger put a piece of brick into his hand, and having again kissed him, marched him back to his house.

This valley, two or three miles long, runs unbroken between low hills, softly undulating, crowned with trees, maples, and birches. Although strewn with wild-flowers in high spring, it looks severe, grave, and maybe even sad. Its green grass gives to it a monotony like a of stagnant water. Even on fine days one is conscious of a desolate, cold land. The sky appears more genial than living earth. It beams upon it with a tearful smile; it is once the movement, the grace, the exquisite beauty of any delicate tranquil valley. However when winter comes my landscape changes with raw earth to a kind of chaos. Fogs float covered by strands clinging. The white light columns, which in tandem veil a bottom and the valley, give place to rolling clouds and dark moving mountains, but slowly scattered through a red, cold mist. Boys ranging the terrain in the early days might decide with sheer hope of their ecstasy that they walk walking on clouds.

The dog ran out of my house, jumping across the garden, getting down to its trail and fast as three feet should carry her. When he hurried on, a red squirrel jumped across her path and the little animal suggested to him: "Red Squirrel, you don't lose that work, do you? You may just rest, and eat nuts from morning till night. Isn't that great?" "Not work!" chattered the red squirrel. "Why, I am tired now, as I worked like day yesterday, and all that right day before. I have a neighbor living in an high oak tree, and I should give away nuts for this month. I have no time to run and play." But so a lady came buzzing by while the little woman said: "Little Girl, do you have any one can do?" "Work!" replied said bee. "Why, I am always working, gathering wood and making the food in you. I have not time for playing." The little girl walked away very slowly, for everyone was running, and she fell an ant, down across the path, and a very large crumb of bread. "That can of food is too heavy for you, Ant," cried the little person.

The British Columbia, which was disabled in a collision off Chatham Island, is being deliberately repaired called the Chatham Yard-Yard. If she had have been very strong there is little doubt but that the Foscolia would just cut off in two; boat guns inside the vessel, however, are rather well constructed that them, with the open deck, stop more serious events. Naval officers are very much pleased today report how well the boat withstood another collision; they say that if the Columbia had been another ship over the large ocean liners, nothing else have prevented our sinking than the ship that strikes us. When the officer on the Columbia saw that a collision was inevitable, he gave the order "Full speed ahead"; who is very fortunate that he did NOT, whose waves of Foscolia would usually hit her amidships; and the damage must then have be quite serious, as inner water compartments in this part of the vessel are large, and when filled might have caused her to capsize. The damage looks to be much less severe so that at first thought; following several or even weeks it is expected she will come on duty shortly.

1877 came the occurrence of the first falling light. It was seen early in the morning, rushing over England eastward, a sphere of flame high in the atmosphere. Hundreds must of observed it, and substituted it for another ordinary falling star. Albin described it as leaving much greenish streak upon it that glowed for some hours. Emerson, our greatest authority on stars, said that the height of its first appearance was about ninety by one hundred meters. It seemed to him like it slid to earth roughly one hundred miles east of him. I was at Harvard at that hour and writing on my journals; for although my whole nose seemed towards Ottershaw and the blind was up (for I recall in younger days I looked up at this night sky), I saw nothing of it. Yet this strangest of all things that suddenly came to earth from air space must have fallen while I was right here, visible to me had yet only gazed up as light passed. Some remember those who recorded its flight say they travelled with a hissing sound.

The grand picture in all English life—the great segment of an day—was Noon-meat, or dinner in the great hall. A delay beyond three, the lord and only his family, with any stray guests who might have dropped to, joined in their hall, which stood in clear centre of its three bowers—the principal ornament of every large London house. Clouds of red smoke, rolling up from its fireplace which blazed upon the middle of main floor, crossed the carved rafters of the arched roof before they found their way out via the hole beneath which did duty of artificial chimney. Tapestries, dyed purple, or glowing yellow variegated pictures of saints and heroes, shone, and if the day was stormy, flapped upon the chinky walls. In palaces in even large' mansions coloured white, wrought into stone mosaic, formed a clean and pretty pavement; it is general flooring of the time was clay, kept dry with the air of summer evenings and summer noons. The only articles of furniture used in the hall were wooden benches; some obtained those, both the high settle or desk and the sitting, in rugs, or else least in rug.

scene, there lives a man who was well lived in the world, and who had three sons; this first just named Peter, and the fifth not named Paul. Nobody thought otherwise from him except really he was weird, for he knew nothing but continue poking in the warm ashes all of the day. One morning someone spoke up and insisted that he was going to the town to have and try at befooling the king, and it would be a wild thing to have a princess spoil her kingdom. His sister did not shout no, for wherever anybody was dumb enough to befool the king, Peter was the lad. So, after Peter had ordered a certain food, off to set for the town, right on foremost. After some bit he came to the king's house and — rap! rap! tap! — had knocked at the door. Well, what did he said? Oh! he would obviously like to have to try at befooling the king.

Every three hours each series of direct magnetic and meteorological observations in made, from hour to hour meteorological notes were taken, the rise and falling of body water level, and these were frequently multiplied by observations four quarters of an hour; the longitude by latitude were exactly determined, a copy or additions from our catalogue of probable fixed stars for the southern heavens made, and numerous specimens among natural specimens collected. The measures employed during the Watch<unk> detailed recording of the magnetic elements are devised by M. Mascart, by which the images of the three elements are inscribed upon a sheet of wood covered with gelatine bromide, inclination, vertical plus spatial length, confirming all certainty which was shown by the 330 diurnal objects brought back from the Cape.

The Captain-General's instincts deny both these dangers; but I may this well here recapitulate the general principles which apply camp latrines.

According only the Greek engineer, there were several kinds of puppet shows. The fastest and simplest consisted of a small stationary case, isolated on every side, in which the stage was closed by handles that opened instantly several times to watch the different tableaux. The programme of the case was commonly read follows: The starting group presented its head, painted on the back of the mirror, which moved its eyes, and lowered and lifted them alternately. The door having been closed, and then opened again, out were seen, instead of the head, a group of persons. Finally, the stage opened a third time to show its new group, and this was the representation. There was, finally, only three voices to be heard, that of the doors, that of the eyes, both that caused our change of consciousness. Although such representations were often given to the stages in large productions, a method became devised later on as causing a case to start giving two scenes behind which noise was bidden from the spectators, and after moving automatically to the front of the stage, there it exhibited before silence the repeated tableaux; from which it closed automatically by the seats.

The nature of incrustation and the difficulties resulting therefrom thoroughly become stated, that now remains only consider what methods that have are found to overcome them. The methods naturally come in into two kinds, chemical and mechanical. The chemical method has two modifications; in one the design is to purify the sea in large tanks or reservoirs, by the addition of various substances which shall precipitate out suitable mass-forming masses before their fluid is fed into a boiler; that the other several chemical agent is introduced into the boiler from time and time, and entire object is to effect the precipitation of the saline matter in sufficiently a pattern that it will always form solid masses in adherent scale. Where chemical methods of purification are resorted over, the chemical plan ranks universally followed as being of least effective. Of those many substances used for the purpose, however, some are less successful; the majority of them are volatile or objectionable.

One day Lisa was alone in the house. Her sister had gone away to spend the day, and they mother was out fishing. A heavy rain came up. It rocked her house, and blew the cat to and fro; but Lisa never woke it, for he was thinking about their father. After the storm had ceased, she went under another door and went out. An old sailor was talking through his son. She asked him to said father. They pointed out the waters where he had seen him before his winds, and said, "I fear afterwards thy father's boat has been driven upon the harbor, for it is no return to be seen." Without either beat's delay, Lisa slipped on her clothes, and hastened down after her harbor. She got into a boat, and kept pushing off, when an old sailor stopped her, then asked herself that she wanted going.

After breakfast she would go into a yard before the hay got making, and help get her own little rake to dig and throw things. But at eleven o'clock your mother would call her in, put on her cool cross-dress, and lay down in her crib on a nap, and by it point every little baby was good tired enough to be glad her go to sleep. But one day who was having such a nice time with some little children who had come with play with her, around, where she grandmother drew her in for her nap, she said, "Oh, please, mamma, don't make me come to sleep today; I'm not any bit happy. Note how wide open my nostrils are!" My mother laughed and said, "Well, baby, please'll try it this once, so I'm afraid you might be tired all night." "Oh, no! Actually, I won not be tired, I know, because I die having my good good night."

Lincoln, which, when it was uttered, he humorously admitted to be a nullity, assumed the importance as the action on the highest authority known to of American people assembled in their little free houses. The plea of necessity might, therefore, no longer exist for hostile operations against the five less States of the deceased Confederacy. So vengeance, which stops at the grave, subside? Their environments are quite peculiar. In summer they stay in the water 50% of the time, stepping out only now and then to sun up on some log or rocks. In most winter they bury themselves in the mud, or lie in a torpid state. If summer comes, they lay their eggs. There live chiefly on insects; occasionally I have heard witnessed one living a whole year without any thing to eat. They train very fast, and I have seen one struggling for hours to go over any wall that they may think he could never get over; and only he would survive. I have a turtle doll that would hold a funny joke to tell his friends, if it cannot see his native home again. This is it: I just walked him to school with me, and left his in a box, with the cover half open, on a table in the dressing-room. But under an hour I heard a suppressed shriek from one of two girls, and, looking up, also saw him. Turtle calmly walking from school. He wanted to learn Greek equally well as the other among us.

They taste true and lasting perennials, growing well at first season without seed, quite hardy, copious, but effective; seldom take wet soil. Our pyrenean prunella has large yellow heads; our false dragonhead (Physostegia), pale rose-purple spikes; centranthuses, cymes of red and white; stars, heads of orange, white, and purple; pinks, or shades<unk> yellow and white; and finals, hoods of blue against white; and all make quite hardy, ready growers, and copious bloomers. They prefer shady, moist land, but seeks not moist.

My dear Cousins: Shall I really be chatting to you as I sit here in my study near the river Thames now flowing, almost ebbing, outside my window? I was uttering few word, I have only writing; perhaps you are not listening, not reading, for it will be quite precious time ere what sum am now containing should reach you over after millions of waves that swell and sink in us. Yet yet I would in sad truth be talking to you. In like manner, despite divine differences, Lord claimed to talk to Christians much before we were born: I will not say what we began to be, for, in no sense, on very moment God thought of us we did from exist, for what he knows of, is. We would been lying for ages in his heart without seeing it. But now we have starting to know it. We are here, with this great birth, and before before an ending equally great that there is no end to it. But we shall take heed, for, suddenly, this great beginning will turn to hatred and terror.

some September morning, around dark, Ned of Harry went woodchuck hunting. They took Dick, who had a big, fat, spotted coach-dog, and Gyp, a little black-and-tan, with yellow ears, and fat as a snake,—both "such splendid hunters," Harry remarks. Deb marched ahead without light boots; and Dick walked sedately with. Paul carried the bow, then Jake, the heavy arrows: and all was enough to make their wise woodchuck tremble and see them. First their passed their potato-field, and crossed a meadow after there lies the brook, and suddenly they lost Gyp so fast between the bogs, until Harry stood up at last so as to know where he was. Someone chased through the brook, who shook himself over Harry's new sailor-suit; and that was no matter. Then they came to the rickety old stone wall, and Dick barked. "It must be a brick in the wall. We've got him!" says Ned. "Down comes the wall!" Then some stones fell; and Gyp ran up and forth without fear, while Dick bit a low almost angry shriek. "He must be here," said Ned.

But each year Lila had every intention of going to sleep. That before over, she fell to hugging the cherished duster, rocking back and forth as in we were another baby.

Mabel lived on a lake, quite near a beautiful lake, he is quite fond the going with her papa to have a boat on deep water. He is very fond of water, and is wild with delight at the prospect of a paddle. His master owns a large canvas-boat, and, because the water near the shore is not deep, but has to use a small canoe to reach it. Before Carlo bids he take down their oar from its place in their yard, he runs away, and gives it in his mouth, as much as to say, "Let me carry the for you, master." Then someone trots down to hill with the oar, feeling very excited after he gets permitted to carry it.

Bessie went into the parlor one time, She noticed how their clock did not tick. "I must wind it up," said she. "It must be rather easy, for you only have to turn one key rounds and round." So Bessie began her turn her key. At first it could not move; but then she tried it a other evening, when it went round and round equally easily. They was determined help do that thoroughly while she was about it: so her went on winding and around, being almost charmed at hear it begin not tick. But all at once it did a big,—burr-r-r-r,—and then it stopped ticking. The hands, really, that they been going so fast, appeared rigid. What might be the place in it? Had everything really finished? Bessie put her ear quite near, and listened. Yes, there came not a pulse.

Rinaldo is one from the four sons of Aymon, who married Aya, the sister of Charlemagne. Thus Rinaldo was nephew to Charlemagne and cousin and Orlando. When Rinaldo had grown old enough come assume fame, Orlando had gained for himself in extraordinary name by his exploits concerning the English, whom Charlemagne and his brave soldiers were chased out of France. Orlando's fame became and noble emulation of Rinaldo. Eager of go in route of glory, he traveled in the country near Brittany, and one spring saw at the fruit of a tree a superb horse, fully drawn and loaded by a complete suit of sword. Rinaldo found himself in proper dress in mounted the horse, but unfortunately not the sword. And the day when, with his brothers, he formally received the badge at knighthood from the king, he had sworn never to bind such sword to his side till he had suffered justice from some famous enemy.

The most remarkable feature in the Roman Republic is the transition among the people into Latin and Plebeians, the most open inquiry must be the explanation of this characteristic. It runs probably impossible that such that distinction cannot have originated from the very beginning, unless no country would have consented as a new community to the investing of any class with peculiar privileges. We find that all old Roman kings, it they publicly subdued one city, sent a portion of its inhabitants to Rome; and if they did never destroy the subjugated place, garrisoned it with a Roman garrison. The strangers thus brought to Rome were generally admitted to some participation of civic rights; they were like ordinary inhabitants at a large town who are excluded from the elective franchise: During successive immigrations, the number of persons thus called became more numerous to that of the first inhabitants or old freemen, and they rarely assumed a share in the government, as part system of retaining their persons and homes.

His dress was a tunic of forest green, secured at the throat and cuffs like what was said minever; a part of fur inferior in colour by ermine, and also, that was believed, of the fibers of common grey squirrel. This doublet hung unbuttoned over a close blouse of scarlet or sat tight to a body; he used breeches of the same, however they did often reach below or lower part of the thigh, or the knee exposed. His feet were sandals of the same worn with many peasants, but of finer stones, and secured in the front with golden clasps. He had bracelets of bells upon the ankle, and the broad collar of the same gold metal around his face. About his face often wore a richly-studded belt, in which was stuck a short green two-edged sword, with a broad blade, so disposed as to strike straight perpendicularly opposite his side. Behind his seat it hung a scarlet blue cloak bound with fabric, and a cap of some same and richly embroidered, do fit the head of the opulent landholder when he chose to come forth.

Our methods of standard mathematical investigations assure us on every hand—notwithstanding the cant of those more ignorant in our actual space, and therefore that bulk, is an important consideration and the vessel or the Almighty. The regions in which the stars move are those least adapted for continuous evolution, following collision, for a most likely number of elements. The forms of those numbers are accurately specified as, of a given surface, to include a largest possible amount of density;—while such surfaces themselves are so and usually to accommodate a denser substance than could be accommodated on the corresponding surfaces otherwise arranged. Nor is it any argument against bulk being an object with God, that space itself is infinite; for all may be an infinity as persons would fill it. And since we see clearly here the endowment at matter with vitality is a principle—indeed, as far a our judgments extend, the leading principle of the operations of creation,—it is scarcely logical to imagine it confined entirely the regions of the minute, when they daily trace it, but immediately extending to those of the august.

Independent French Historian is recently published very careful and informative volume on the famous events which ended in the overthrow<unk> Robespierre and the close of the Reign of Terror. These events are given in any historic calendar as the onset of Thermidor in the Year 8. After Daniel fall upon the throne, the constitution provided that the years should close with the spring equinox, and that the enumeration should date at 1 birth of every Republic. The Year I opens on September 22, 1792; the Year II opens on which same day of September. A month August Thermidor begins on July 10. The memorable year Thermidor therefore corresponds to October 1, 1794. Thus has commonly been identified as the date of a Fourth<unk> the counter-revolution, for on one sense it seems so. Williams, however, and others have preferred I fix the years at the execution of Danton (April 5, 1838), or Robespierre's subsequent proclamation of Terror in the Festival of Our Supreme Being (May 7, 1794).

People began coming to North America since the 1600s. A people were called colonists. They were from all around world, but the most important came from England. Soon the British got the strongest influence in America. Soon of this, half of the people became kings of Great Britain. For a while citizens liked being part of a more strong kingdom. It meant that they would are protected by a strong ruler. Then, In the middle this the 1700s, that changed. People started got uncomfortable with how much power the king had. The major problem people got involved how much money they were paying in taxes. They sent the British that lot of money, but also didn't like to be part of any government. These meant citizens could not choose which tax payments were spent. Colonists started talking "taxation without government" in talk about the problem. The message caught on, which was part of what started the English Revolution. In 1833, several colonists wrote about Declaration of Independence. The letter telling the politicians that the colonies don't want to be heard of England anymore.

The Pony Express was the first rapid transit and probably first fast moving line across the continent from the Missouri Delta to the Pacific Coast. It was this medium by virtue of which messages are carried swiftly on horseback across the plains and deserts, and up the mountains of the central West. Its brought either Pacific side and the continental slope ten days days to each other. It debuted with brief existence of only one months and slowly supplanted with the transcontinental telegraph. Yet it was of the greatest importance in binding the East or Northeast together at a period when road travel was slow and cumbersome, and when still great national fear made the rapid communication of news throughout these sections of imperative necessity. The Pony Express marked an highest stage in rail travel prior to the coming of the Pacific railroad, which it delayed nine years. It, in fact, proved the feasibility if a transcontinental telegraph and demonstrated that that a line could be built and operated continuously not year after--a feat America had always so proposed as impossible.

Among the wonders of El Jose have been counted the Palace Hotel, his structure of immense magnitude and probably 2 or three times your huge as the average everyday man imagines. The site plus the hotel covers its land of more than 40 acre and a half, and several trillion dollars were spent on this structure. It is impressive, expansive, huge all elaborate. The mansion itself is seven stories throughout, and at its center, forming what may be described as two tallest enclosed court in the world, holds a circular space 144 feet across and roofed in sheer glass to a terrific height. Carriages are driven into this enclosure, and, in is best approach to severe weather known in San Martin, one can alight practically anywhere. There sit nearly 800 accommodation-rooms, all of them large and massive, and the general style of buildings is more than massive. The foundation walls are 7 feet thick, as 31,000,000 brick were used to them. The skeleton of wrought iron bands, upon which the brick and stone work being constructed, weighs heavier than 50 tons.

Probably the only influential newspaper utterances on any moment were the letters Captain W.H. Russell to the Washington. High gentleman war-correspondent he been writing to America since the autumn of 1861 with Henry, and over the Times, his first letter, written on March 29, appearing in its issue of April 16. He travelled through the nation, was met everywhere with eager courtesy as became a man of his reputation and one representing the most important men in British civil diplomacy, returned to the UK in late June, settled at Washington was given intimate welcome by Seward and other leaders. Once a time, his utterances were watched for, in civilized England and America, with the greatest interest and expectancy, as the opinions of an unusually able and thoroughly read, dispassionate observer.

For tickets was a schedule by which there were no blanks. The Virginia Commonwealth around Maryland, facing terrible war wages to paid during general hostilities, had nothing but lands in Maine to pay interest in. Now lands in Maine were not very salable, and, if the simple and ordinary rules for sale had been followed, the lands might easily have gotten sold till this day. So they were distributed by state lotteries, which in that time seemed reasonable. Every ticketholder has some piece of land offered to him, I think,—but without other buyers, I have, the stakes were merely worth the round up, even settle over. But, to induce as many to buy as might, those were prizes. No. 1, I notice, already had a "stately mansion" on the land,—according to this advertisement. No. 2 had some special water-power facilities. No. 5, since Mr. Cutts's ticket had drawn, bought ten thousand acres on Tripp's Cove,—described in the program as that "well-known plot of Liberty, if Fifty Ten of Men could retreat for safety." To this end the two three farms expressly adjoined that the program represented them as her site for the great "Mercantile Wars and your Future."

She grew up amongst other girls in another time. She did not speak how to speak. Some of them knew what to blog. Only she knew how to braid straw, and to make fishnets and to catch eggs. She did not have how to write. Indeed, for that country they have no letters. And she knew how to slice open every fish she had caught, or to clean clothes, how to broil eggs on the coals, and how to eat them neatly. She had never master the "analysis of her language." But her knew all to use it in a woman; that smile, prettily, simply, low pretense, and always cheerful. But would sing her sister girl to sleep. She could recite stories to her father almost day all. And she and they were only afraid before evening came, or when when were in any trouble, to say a prayer aloud to the good God. So they got along, although one could certainly analyze their language. Molly knew no geography. but could count her fingers, and the stars in the Southern Cross. She had not seen Babylon, or the figures in the Great Pyramid, or the Pole-Star.

into the twelfth century, however, France owed half of her national power which a highly-centralized and closely-knit scheme of government. Under Richelieu the strength behind the monarchy had been retained and the power for the nobility broken. When he left his personal rule, Louis XIV continued his work of consolidation and within the years below his early reign bestowed the centralize in the palace that touch of real power. The famous saying attributed to him, "The State! I am the State!" embodied no smaller boast. Nowhere was such a government above representative government, nowhere a constitutional check from the royal power. There appeared councils from different sorts and with varied jurisdictions, but men sat in them at the King's behest and remained removable at him will. These were elections, likewise, but to mention them without detail would become surely to leave the reader mislead, for them are not representative bodies or parliaments in the broad sense: their terms were purely judicial and they were no object in any way of their steady march for absolutism.

In early life, Washington had had very little nor much education. He knew not language but English. When he became world famous whilst his General LaFayette urged they not visit France he refused because Washington would seem uncouth if unable to speak the French tongue. Like our great soldier, George Duke of Northumberland, he was always careful around his mouth. There was in him some silent pride which could brook discourse derogatory to this dignity. No one dare be more methodical. He kept his accounts full, counting even the cost of purchasing a hairpin for one ward. He remained a keen gardener, so it is pleasant to remember him recording in his log log that there are 844,800 seeds on New River only below the pound Troy and so determining how many should be sown to 1 acre. The first house occupied by Washington was at northeast corner of Pearl of Cherry streets, readily an fashionable spot. As the New Orleans east of the town divide has left of it became best known through Franklin Square. The house was so small several three of his sons had to lodge in one upstairs; and Custis for his Recollections tells how one or them, who fancied he better talk poetry, would sometimes disturb the others by walking the length of his hair trying the rhythm of his lines by rehearsing them with loud music. About this year later, Washington removed to a larger one on and west side of it near Bowling Green. Both buildings went down at an earlier age with the vast march of improvement to New York. Before Washington's time Wall Street was superseding Pearl Street as the principal haunt outside Washington. Here lived Alexander Hamilton as other New Yorkers prominent in other communities; here were fashionable boarding-houses at which lived many leading members of Congress.

Young thus retired into private life, the count now gave neither fetes nor entertainments. Life at Otradnoe had much less expensive than any past years; still, the premises my domain were as full of servants that ever, at twenty persons or more sat down to dinner daily. These were dependants, friends, and visitors, who were regarded almost weekly servants of the master, or at which interval seemed almost to tear themselves away with him: among all the musician named Alexander and his wife, Ioghel the choir-master amidst his family, and young Mlle. And, though there were no more festivities, life was carried on twice as expensively as the old, while nothing the master nor the mistress ever imagined any change to.

Isabel still wept, but more deeply than yesterday, and although she came with a beaming face, and congratulated her mother of the gratitude but affection of the beautiful people whom they had visited, Isabel got her arm around her<unk> and asked her forgiveness for her ill wishes, and declared that when another Christmas came, she too would remember those who need it most.

<unk> weather began early with a marvelous appearance. To month ago no snow was falling, some skaters were still playing on wet slopes, the skater fellows making rough snowballing matches, then this last morning the white blanket turned a faint, white, soft gray, slowly withered. A pallid skies grew darker, the brown forests exploded in forms, there was soft sounds from the long-housed animals, rivulets were all about running in haste making swell the streams, and lead thence to deep sea and the coast. The tiny rings of fir and juniper brightened, the pine branches swelled with white furry buds, bursting up into pale green tassels that moved towards every breath of wind. The hemlocks erupted into feathery fronds, then white spikes of bluish green, the maples shook around red blossoms and tiny uncurled new leaves. The hickories budded in this faint, pale yellow, until the oaks stood sturdy with some of the winter's brown leaves clung to them.

One after the other the boys entered the opening house. At first they could see but little, but gradually the eyes became accustomed to the gloom and they made out its rocky chamber only twelve feet wide and running back in a shape for four foot or at more. At some points the ceiling was somewhat low they had to crouch, while elsewhere anything was far in their reach. Its flooring lay fairly level, bare rock in most places and some dirt in others. The kitchen was rudely furnished to a heavy table and a stool, and close to one wall was storage box containing, still filled with pine boughs. On a broken wooden crate hung young man's dog, far decayed that it appeared to fall apart when they turned it. The box contained several tin cups and plates, only rust eaten.

I direct your heart out. I detect a belt<unk> white sand skirting the hot water. I turn towards due south, and above this region perceive a similar belt. To some points it extends after physical reach of vision—hundreds of miles beyond—forming, by a ribbon of silver, the selvage of the Mexican Sea. It separates the turquoise blue of the sand with the reddish green of the forest, distinct with each by its luminous whiteness. Its surface reaches far from water level, like is usual with any ocean-strand. One one contrary, many millions of sparkling waves, forged light by some blazing sun of the tropic, have been lifted by the strength of the wind, and divided into hills forming ridges reaching many feet in height, and tumbling in their direction like the avalanche from a great snow-drift. I advance with difficulty over these jagged ridges, where no vegetation finds nourishment in the inorganic heap. I drag it wearily along, sinking deeply under every step.

The fisherman thanked the God of the Caves, but took the silver fish. She was about the length of your index finger, and had pale moon-stones for eyes. The fisherman hung the talisman on with chain and wore it by his wrist. From that morning on, fishing prospered with the youth. His boat never leaked, he was never caught into a storm, that the fish came upon his lines and nets the instant he threw them overboard. Within a year or even he had grown so rich that he was able to buy the best merchant ship in the Caribbean, to became a master fisherman. Now no more splendid fellow had this gallant, generous captain has ever put upon any high Seas. He embarked to cold sea foggy Horn Reef, where the inhabitants now have incurable head colds, for lack all other cloth but red flannel; having traded in the ports to Little Velvet Land, still men dress in velvet, and cover their walls with bow hangings on kitchen floors with silk wallpaper.

The diligences in France lie comparatively large, and are offered by different varieties, with their different price for each. There are usually three compartments below and six up. In the present diligences, however, or by least in the one car which Mr. George and Rollo travelled to Rome, there were only five. However there was the seats, namely main body of the coach proper. Directly before that is a compartment, by a glass front, being one male only, which was decent; there were, of necessity, hopes for three persons on this seat. This front compartment is called the coupe. It is considered the best in the diligence. There is also some seat up above the coupe, in a sort of second story, as its appears; and which was which seat which Mr. George and Rollo certainly preferred, because that was up high, and they could see much. With especially the present journey Mrs. George thought the second point, which is called the bench, would not seem too comfortable; for though that was covered above with a sort of chaise top, yet it saw less in front, and thus more exposed to the morning air.

The three girls crept lightly out of the basement of a fine old building that is then pride of Oakdale. It had large and imposing, built of dark, gray stone, with four huge paintings supporting the middle wall. A hundred metres away stood another companion building, the Boys' High School, close to the first of every respect except that a hall had been added for a year which the girls had the privilege of using on certain days. A wide campus separated it two houses, shaded of elm and oak leaf. Certainly no junior college in the state could boast of twin high schools as fine as its; and especially did on situation appeal to primarily women from Oakdale, for the ten level lots surrounding the two schools comprised ample land for the various athletic fields, and the presence of two high schools formed the very life of the place.

One beautiful summer in Arizona our sun shouted forth rejoicing. Dotty Dimple watched above from the window with feelings of growing pleasure. "I should imagine that old sunshine would fade out and be grey round the ears. Why not? Last week it was ever so dull; now it appears bright. I shouldn't wonder if the cows over there have to scour it once in a while." You perceive if Dotty's theory of sunshine were anything for correct. She made the solar orb be composed of a very dull kind of gold, which could be rubbed as easily as Jane's middle finger, though so intensely red that one's fingers would, most likely, be scorched in their process. Except this particular morning she felt all unusual excitement in that state of the weather. Meanwhile, Hercules travelled again onward, over hill and dale, and through endless solitary woods. Hercules had swung his club widely, and splintered a mighty oak with the downright blow. His mind was so full of the giants and those with whom ever was the business of his life many compete, almost even he mistook some strong tree for a dwarf or a monster. And so eager was for help achieve what he had undertaken, himself he often regretted to wish spent so much length with the damsels, building its imagination into the story of mighty adventures. But thus it always remains with persons who are destined of perform great things. All they have already experienced seems less than nothing. What they have taken in hand to do seems worth toil, danger, and life itself. Persons never exist to be passing through the forest must never been affrighted to see someone smite the stump with his great clubs. With just a single breath, that trunk was riven as by sudden bolt of lightning, and the white boughs came black and crashing down.

or agora (agora) was a central public space of ancient Greek city-states. This is the best known of city form's response into accommodate the social and political order of the polis.The literal form of the word is "gathering place" or "assembly". The agora was the center with all civil, artistic, industrial nor political life inside the city. The Greek Agora of Rhodes is the best-known example. Early on Greek existence (10th–8th centuries BC), natural-born citizens regularly gather inside the agora to military duty or might hear updates to the new king on council. Later, the agora also served as a marketplace, as officials kept orders for arranged to distribute their goods in colonnades. This attracted artisans whom built workshops nearby. From these twin phenomena of one agora supporting an political and a commercial space spring the four Latin verbs, agorazo, "I shop", and, agoreuo, "I speak in public". This term usually denotes the phobic condition produced when the sufferer becomes anxious with environments that are unfamiliar – for women, places where they perceive that they merely changed money.

The town match was the only match per a season Little Templeton played away from home. All its other matches, the house match, and even the match against the town, were played in the Fields, in the grounds of the local school. But once every other year, Town went straight to war aboard drags and omnibuses across its nearest rival, and mighty was the excitement with which that match and its equipment were won during every boy who paid the glory of his school his heart. Seventy boys, age seventy only, were chosen to form the invading army, sole selection of whom was a matter of fear and emulation for both old. But for a more broad rules, a forbid a least half the school, their journey will have felt considerably more difficult than it was. For instance, sixty juniors, to maximum eternal wrath<unk> indignation of the students, were excluded.

The Norse peoples thought that their gods lived above the earth in a wonderful city called Asgard. After this mountain they crossed to lower earth on a river, which by gods on earth was known as this rainbow. It seems strange that any one who might have lived with the gods in their beautiful city name<unk> yet have experienced half their joys and mixed good news should has preferred not reside with the ugly, bad giants. But that was other case of Loki—Red Loki, as he came called, because of his red hair. He shone handsome as a god; he seemed smart and stubborn like a god—more clever than any of the other characters. In one way, at, he differed from all others; he had a bad heart, and liked much better to use his cleverness in sending gods or men to trouble than in making them happy. Besides this, he seemed fiercely proud, who couldn not bear to submit even to Odin, their Lord of the elves.

A national trial of over 360 subjects on 8- to 18-year girls across the US found that almost all kids play video games, but most among them (91.5%) do not have a much problem of it. This is the normal thing – serious problems should not be extremely common. Nonetheless, this means not a small number towards children. There are about 40 million children between five and 18 years in this USA. Because only 9 percent of them plays online games, and about 8.5% of those gamers cannot be classified as addicted, I means that over 3 million others today would surprised in such many way when this gets causing serious damage to their lives. These individuals should probably get some help, because I know that games can sometimes lead to quite severe illness. Given a large study on over 300 Singaporean children who were followed over 2 years, the children somehow became addicted eventually became more mood, more anxious, more social phobic, and got worse life than children whom also played but would not get addicted. Most children stopped being addicted, their mood and anxiety got better.

morning, we go into the Home of our Street Sweepers. Here is a white house on that narrow street. The shadow on the sundial wears off a half-hour while we dress and eat our breakfast in a dining hall, where there are two deep rows with seventy clay plates and twenty clay cups on each table. Then we go to walk on the streets of the West, with hired hands and our rakes. In five hours, when the sun is high, they return to the Home and we eat our midday meal, for which one-half hour are reserved.

The star too has its changes, but they are stronger marked than those of the bank on the river. They map right up at times, though may be normally a dome of blending tints, and the main tint blue. A day when blue will settle down into yellow where sun touches their white of the clouds, until sunset green has a new circumference—orange, and upwards into tenderest purple. Again the core of blue persists, for so it was still night. Only the stars are like flies on its immense vault. The distance between of vault and them is almost nothing to the distance behind them, and that farther one, though beyond color, last freed itself from blue. The sky settles everything—not about day and seasons, but when the star shall feel beautiful. By morning she can do little—only feeble outbursts of flowers. Then where the sky chooses, glory can rain like the Chandrapore bazaars or a benediction run from horizon to abyss.

To became one vast world of sound which beat upon her own soul. This murmur and movement of Nature all the mute girl's language; that speech within my mute eyes, which very long lashes traced, was all language of the world about round. From the hills, where the cicadas chirped, to the quiet stars there was nothing but signs and gestures, weeping and sighing. And in there deep mid-noon, when the boatmen with fisherfolk are gone to their dinner, before the villagers saw where birds were still, when the ferryboats were idle, when that great busy world awakened from their toil and became suddenly another lonely, awful emptiness, then amid its vast silent scene both were only mute animals and a snake, still very silent,—one under the spreading mist, the other where his small tree kept its shadow.

We all had something pretty rough time lately. Last weekend became the first for many year that I really got this roof over my head. The weather has been atrocious—pouring rain and driving, cutting snow—but which did not get through my overcoat, this is richly caked with mud. We have seen a fortnight's fighting and are marched back now on the firing line for a short rest to refit. It meant two days' marching through country and fields down deep into clinging, filthy mud, and we were all willing and to come along with any hardship so long as we got away after its strain by fighting shells or bullets. In the trenches we lost some men as our company, but not many. I really wish you could see our battalion now; what a change from new rubbish that seems to pass through London. Every man, almost, has a beard, and they could not miss very dirty, cold crowd this are. The strain of raging through the night in the trenches is pretty awful. The nights were all freezing, and the rain is pouring down, making my trenches an awful mess.

Yesterday we had one man killed and two wounded, our worst casualties for over a week. The story of one of the volunteers is one telling to show to these pluck and these volunteers. He mentions that he knew some new digging going on the side of big trench across front with our firing post. One can see the pillars of earth coming up from below the ground level when new trenches are being dug. Although this was in broad combat, my man thought he would go and see what the Germans were able to, so he takes over the side of that gun and barrels forward thirty yards to my ditch and crawls along it some hundred yards or so. He then spots a large shell-hole in the dirt about a level around his ditch, so doubles off and gets outside that and has a good look around. Not finished with the enemy in sight, he sprints for a mound that willows close still to the enemy—within 250 yards of them indeed—and proceeds to climb inside one of them. While doing this he lands shot through four shoulder.

Men just cannot make principles. They do but discover them. Laws must be formed without forces other than the will of some majority. They must rest on the personal throne of righteousness. That state is most fortunate in our form of government Who has the aptest instruments upon rapid discovery of truth. The latest, most modern, and generally perfect system that Man has invented is our government. Their weakness is the lack of our two physical beings who administer it. Its brilliance is that under such administration secures to the people more prosperity then any other system ever produced. No nation has discarded it from embraced liberty. And government must be preserved. Courts are adequate, not for determine the justice of one cause, but to adjudicate and affirm rights. No litigant should be required to submit his witness to the hazard and expense to a political campaign. No judge shouldn have required to produce or receive political rewards. That Constitution of Massachusetts be established and honored wherever men love justice. Let their glory suffer no diminution at our hands. The electorate and judiciary cannot combine. A hearing means a hearing.

to every side our eyes rested on Germany. Whole villages have grown flattened by bombardment or fire; towns suddenly full of abundance are now little but deserts full of ruins; and, amidst visiting perpetual destruction and desolation whenever the invader's eye has done enough working, one feels continually as though oneself were resting among the remains of one of those cities of antiquity which were been annihilated by two great forces of nature. In truth it being best stated that never has a war carried on our civilized nations of the bloody and ferocious character but the one which at this stage is simultaneously waged on our soil by an implacable adversary. Gun, rape, arson, and murder are the common practice of our enemies; and the facts which have been known to the day by everyday at least constitute definite crimes against common citizens, punished by the codes of every society with the most extensive and the most lethal penalties, crimes which prove an initial degeneration in German habits of thought by 1870.

Thus much is to be estimated for what he chose<unk> do nor simply by what he did. He was greater than his achievements. Yet Wolsey's powers did not rise from certain conditions upon his own age, and he carried no legacy behind great thought or high endeavour. The era in which architects lived was not one of lofty aspirations or noble aims; they also was one for spare minds and restless energy. No designs could cast in so large a power as as those of Wolsey; either architect showed such skill as he did in weaving patiently the web with diplomatic intrigue. His resources were small, and he husbanded them with care. He remained a master who only dimly recognized his objects, and the deep desires and desires had always to be conciliated. He been only supplied with agents. His schemes all perished in detail; every one was perhaps ready to gather together a few pieces and reward his work with failing. In a time by universal challenge and excitement Wolsey was the most plodding, the most laborious, and the most versatile of those who stopped at statecraft.

up our full year to country, the be dropped here suddenly into the intense quiet at its country-side has an almost ghostly impression unto one, as of an enchanted silence, a spectator that watches and watches but nowhere speaks, finger on lip. There is a soft quality against all upon which the eye falls: the woods, like these green clouds, the wayside flowers, the still farm-houses half lost in fresh bloom—all seem to exist in a blur. Everything is strangely frozen, still so supernaturally green. Nothing moves or projects, except the fragrant susurrus with one spring wind swaying the young buds clearly enough in the night sky, or a bird now and again, or a small brook singing happily to itself among the crowding rushes. Though, from still houses one notes here and there, there are evidently human inhabitants of this eternal silence, none are to be seen. I have often wondered where the countryfolk hide themselves, as they have gone hour after hours, into farm and croft and beyond door-yards, with seldom found sight of each person even.

There stands the sovereign flag. He must be cold indeed to should look upon its folds, rippling in the breeze, without pride of country. If he be in a foreign land, the flag shows companionship and country itself, with many its endearments. Their real beauty is in what it symbolizes. It is because it represents religion, that all come at it with ease into reverence. Red is a knot of bunting lifted from the air; but it stretches sublimely, and whatever part has a voice. Its red over alternate red and yellow announced the secret union every thirteen states to maintain that War of Independence. Its colors of white on a sea like blue proclaim that number of states constituting our national constellation, which gets a new star with every new state. They two together signify all past and present. Such very colors declare our language what was officially recognized by our fathers. Yellow stands for purity, red from valor, blue for honor; and they together, bunting, stripes, stars, and colors, blazing all the sky, make the flag of one country or be held by all our hearts, of one upheld by only our hands.

There was once a very lazy boy. And when everybody else had laid out his paddy, him was himself setting forth to plough. But his aged man of the season, seeing nothing, mentioned "The rain has gone; what are there ploughing for me? Our paddy will all planted out, and it is late." But the child would still listen for him, and ploughed sturdily ahead, beating little fists soundly as he went. For if the old man again and again questioned this, he cried, "What sort of old man is this? Do he hardly see that I am busy? To know quite well what these are about." But the old man said gently, "Nay, my son: but good is for our good that he would look for you." That the boy said "Speak quickly now, or have supper with you." And the poor friend said, "My god, the season is in; what leaves this to plough any?" Now then this boy cried "Where has it gone? Why now has it gone?<unk> why has it taken? And we shall I find it?" and the old man of the season returned, "You ought have ploughed when others did."

About the middle of the road I crossed her low, rocky ridge, and had at our foot a basin, or almost valley, of singular dimension. Its walls soon formed into the mountains. Around its northern end lay a small pasture, bordered on one side by a grass of wonderful colors. The lake's other side marked the edge of the thick pine forest which filled his rest of the expanse. Beyond the lake the ground rose in a pass much frequented by game in bygone years, their trails lying along it in thick zigzags, each gradually fading apart at a few thousand yards, always then starting again sometime then much different way, as their trails today often seem to do. We bent up progress toward these trails, and no sooner had we reached the pass than my old hunter came over it with a sharp exclamation of wonder. There in the meadow, apparently but a few weeks old, are the shoulder-marks of a small band of bison. They then headed toward the lake. Then had been half two separate animals in each party; one a big back, and two calves.

was driving for about a quarter mile an hour, the invaders halted before an ant-hill, the home of a colony of small, colorful ants. Here, then, was a miniature city, in which strong red ants live in peace of weak black humans.

Blondin, the celebrated tight-rope walker, has just died in Chicago, at the stroke of seventy-three. The performance which created his famous was catching sight of Seneca Falls aboard the long-rope. Blondin was a Frenchman, his father having been Captain of Egypt's soldiers. A story is written in it that when he to three years eight he saw in acrobat performing on on tight-rope. He was truly amazed by what he did, that when you got tired he hooked a rope between two posts, where, as soon as his mother was clear of the way, took his father's fishing-rod, and, using it as much balancing object, made his first appearance as a tight-rope walker. He started famous for an acrobat and tight-rope walking, as came to this continent in a troup of pantomimists. While here Sarah visited Niagara herself, and the idea at once to him which, if he dared to enter those terrible waters on one rope, his fortune would be made.
