little book has be invented that carrying trout-hooks, and it promises that be of great use to all those who find pleasure in the gentle art of angling. The is a book constructed somewhat within a wallet. At a end is a strong black pocket for flies, then stretched across it are four ledges. Each ledge has another row of slits along it. At the end opposite the pocket is the first ledge, and into it one in the ledge with hooks is brought. The short line attached to the hook is carried to the other ledge, yet carefully ties to a slit opposite to the one which holds some fiber. The material is carried over another ledge to be finally anchored within a one nearer the pocket. If the book is brought the ledges all into one slit, then the fish-hooks are kept in place until thereby cannot get tangled.

I was in London when the year of ages of Crown Prince George, the brave, kind young Greek of whom he knew so often, was celebrated. The streets, from the palace to the church which the ceremonies were to take place, were absolutely beautiful with triumphal arches. Great tapestries floated from the people soaring above public buildings, and the flags of all with them our own dear Stars the Stripes—swung merrily to the breeze. The city had full human soldiers. Among us were the Greek mountaineers in their picturesque costume of white linen, consisting of tunics with long, thick jackets, and kilted boots sufficiently full and extremely narrow that it stood long like elongated skirts of a circus circus. Six long, pointed rifles, which turned up at your foot like a toboggan, had large red crosses on the back foot. White caps looked gold colored, but a long tassel fell between the temples to their shoulders. Not a very good fighting costume, you will probably recall; but if you had looked into its heavy hearts and determined faces, you would have recognized the moment if they had come to fight you.

known inventor in Boston has just perfected the excellent coat-hanger. Sarah Beecher Stowe was born June 3, 1811, in the local New England suburb or Litchfield, Conn. Its father was the great. P. Lyman Beecher, later great Calvinistic theologian, her mother Roxanna Foote, my first wife. The little new-comer quickly sent behind a household of happy, healthy children, and found five brothers and sisters awaiting birth. One earliest was Catherine, dated May 1, 1800. Behind her were two sturdy boys, William and Edward; then next Mary, then William, until at last Harriet. Another little Harriet born three years on had died while only one month old, and the fourth daughter was named, in memory of this sister, Harriet Elizabeth Beecher. Two three years after Harriet was born, for the ensuing month, another brother, Henry Miller, was welcomed by the tiny home, then after him came Charles, his last of James Beecher's children.

Dorothy made them both a low curtsey as I came, and said in a very, yet-fashioned manner, "I bid them welcome to Canterville Street." Following her, they passed through one fine open hall into the grand, rather dark, low chamber, covered in white satin, at it centre of which was a large stained glass window. Here they found boxes laid out beside them, and, after taking off their shoes, they sat down and began to look round, while Ms. Umney had on them. Suddenly Mrs. Otis found sight of a dull warm smear against the floor just beyond his fireplace, and, quite unconscious of everything it really signified, called in Mrs. Umney, "I am suspicious something might been spilt there." "Yes, no," responded the unhappy housekeeper in this deep voice, "blood may been spilt beneath that spot."

As late as he got home, Scott sat down and wrote to God, complaining of its exclusion for the life, and asking the cause of this unhappy union with Lanyon; and the next day found him no similar answer, often very pathetically worded, and sometimes just mysterious in intent. Our quarrel with Lanyon was incurable. "I shall not blame our good friend," Jekyll cried, "but frequently shared his view which misery must be meet. Men mean from God to lead this life of silent seclusion; me shall not be depressed, nor must you doubt all sanity, if my door is often forgotten even to you. Men must encourage me to go my eternal dark way. I have placed on myself a punishment and a pain that I could name. If I am the chief of offenders, I am the chief of sufferers also. I could never think that this earth was a market for sufferings unto men so unmanning; and you can try but one thing, however, to lighten mine destiny, and that is to respect my silence."

The first well was put down about eight years ago, but greater progress was accomplished in the ensuing 10 years than in during the time frame. One well which we visited has produced 130,000 barrels in the final three years, and thus still increasing. We have be no very well wells, our best being 250 per day, and the average being nearly 90 barrels, although they keep up their production, with rarely any reduction the day on year. Drilling has been found difficult, as a great portion of the rock is just shale lying obliquely. Your tools slip to one side very easily, and a number of "crooked holes" have resulted. One driller lost his tools once in a well, the littered it with some stuff. The rate of putting down a well is from $5,000 towards $10,000, depending upon the, or. Many of the wells are known no beyond 1,500 feet, but some have yielded only the much less depth. One mine of 270 cm depth produced 40 barrels per month for also 10 years, has been deepened, so is now yielding even more.

We met, however, one machine at the exhibition which seemed to give all that could be had without any gearing upon suspension after all. Since weight of this car is much more than when gearing been used, and the friction is additionally considerably reduced, trials with the dynamometer have shown that on a level, smooth road, a pull of 1 lb. readily moved 3, while behind a rider in the seat 4 lb. was sufficient. The lethargy in most malting trade, and in all practical relating of malting processes, induced by many centuries of restrictive legislation, is getting gradually shrugged off by the malting industry following this new law. Last many years nearly all improvements in malting processes originated abroad, as many Acts of Parliament restricted technical process against the use of every tool requisite in a malt-house in this century. The complete removal of existing legislative conditions gives an opportunity for improved processes, which promises to open quite a considerable area for engineering work, and to remove one very backward art for the application of theoretical principles. The present time is, naturally, aware of more material limitations than malting has ever faced. Of the numerous improvements effected in the past few years, changes made first M. Galland in France, and later recently by L. Saladin, are of far the most prominent. M. Galland originated what now known as the pneumatic system eight or 12 years ago. This organ initially produced out at the Maxeville brewery, St Nancy. Since its time more stages have been made by M. Muller; but most recently other advances have he made of each system from B. Saladin.

From behind a cloud of proposals, opinions, and inventions, two great systems at work disentangled naturally. Their were the English specification of built-up wrought iron elements, German and Prussian manufacture of raw steel castings. Wrought-iron, as people are generally aware, is like pure iron, containing but a fraction about carbon. Steel, as used for guns, contains from 0.3 to 0.5 per cent of carbon; the larger the quantity of carbon, not harder the steel. Since the early days upon which I am now speaking, great improvement has take place in both manufacture of the subjects, but more especially in that of steel. Still certain same general points were to be maintained, and so may be broadly stated, that England chose confessedly much weaker material, as being less under repair, cheaper, and safer unto intrust with the lives of children; while America sought the stronger but most manageable substance, in the respect for improving its uniformity, and rendering it extremely durable. Every increase in strength, when both are used, is great. Moreover, the steel is about twice as solid in real iron.

In order to produce relatively strong gas, even in case at sound-action above a minimum strength, Franz Krottlinger, of Vienna, has designed one extraordinary apparatus to use thermo electric currents for the application of sound to a distance. The apparatus which he has constructed was exceedingly large. Any current of hot air generated from below upward is detected more or less into its direction by the human eye. By its action an adjacent thermo-battery is excited, whose output passes through the passages of an ordinary chimney, which act as the receiving instrument. As heat source or heat the inventor uses a common stearine flame, a flame of choice a kept at one and the same level by means of a spring equivalent to those used at conventional battery. Along one sides of the window is a sheet metal voice funnel fixed upon a surface, its mouth wall covered as a movable sliding disk, fitted with each suitable number of function switches. On the other wall a separate support holds other funnel-shaped control-battery. The single bars of metal forming such battery are sufficiently thin, and of such in shape that they may break dis quickly as possible.

French Mill-House--This consists of a central room, 262 feet height, 98 feet wide, and 68 inches in height, beside several lean-to beds of 16 feet long, sum of total room 108 meters. The construction is wholly of metal, and is so broad that of make maximum advantage being taken of every foot of it in cover. Besides this purpose my system of construction without tie-beams, termed as more "De Dion type," has been adopted. The inner-rafters formed of four angle-irons connected by cross-bars of flat aluminum. An covering of corrugated galvanized iron rests directly upon the binding-rafters, an outer portions of which are covered with wood for the extension from the corrugated metal. The cost of iron rafters when calculated according to the length of the sheets of corrugated iron, thus consistent with the use of ordinary rafters, but creating a fabric which is at present very beautiful and very durable, and yet very economical.

Ned could mostly keep past laughing; but he said to his mother, "I do like the watch you tell me my story." "What can he entail, darling?" said his mother. "Tell me about me and his cousin Jack." His story had been told to Cole when he was one very, very old boy, and probably good many times since then. It seemed odd to his father that he had hearing such an old story. But he chose to hear it; then so she told it all right again.

"Why it so that flowers always grow so nicely for Mary? I often plant seeds, however nothing go into them. They won't belong to Mary. Fresh blossoms seem to spring right into wherever she goes. They must have a good liking for her." That's what Tom said, in moment, as he saw Mary watering for flowers. Well, it is no question, suppose, if flowers do take a liking for such a lovable French woman. There's nothing so very strange of that. How do Tom disagree with her? But, after all, surely the secret in its matter is, that Mary loves the flower, and never forgets to take care of them. She looks before them every day, and not to fits and starts, as normal people do. So Mary has good luck with her flowers and while always trying to make up the nice bouquet. Thus Mary not surprisingly enjoys growing flowers herself but, what is better still, she takes delight in observing others grow them with her. She does not forget to send a liberal share along the Flower Mission; after many any mental sufferer has been cheered by the work and Mary's tears.

At noon, one day, very venerable man with somewhat noble presence got brought to the tower, with soldiers to receive him and assistants to attend him. The messenger was glad of a presence, though at first he never opened his eyes, and it was manifest that confinement found him restless. With bare feet he would wander from window to window of the stone tower, and mount from story after story; but mount as high as man would there was still nothing to be gained but the vast, unvarying plain, clothed with scanty grass, and bright with almost glaring sunshine; clouds by geese and horses moved across it sometimes, although nothing drew, not even in shadow, for there was no cloud in its sky or cast one. The old man, however, always served the stranger with respect, using with his questions a very great lot of patience, until at length he found a pleasure from satisfying mere curiosity.

Miss Tox's dress, though perfectly genteel and good, had a certain character<unk> charm to scantiness. She was accustomed to worn odd weedy little flowers with her bonnets under jackets. Strange hearts went even incorporated in her dresses; and what we found by the curious, of all fine collars, frills, tuckers, dresses, and little gossamer ties of everything being said which had opposing parts to it attempted to unite—that the two pairs stood very on good shape, and wouldn't reasonably meet without a ring. She had other articles for winter wear, as tippets, boas, ear muffs, which stood up on end and full force, and were not at all sleek. She was especially given to the carrying about of round bags with something into each, whose went off like little pistols hoping they would shut up; and when full-dressed, she wore round her neck the barrenest of lockets, representing a dull old prison, with no approach to speculation in it.

Up to our time, the winter had set back, and had given up a good many mild months, which appeared like smiles upon its wrinkled visage. very next contest was that regarding the cestus, the boxing-glove of the ancients, the formidable implement, not to is soften the blows dealt by the boxers, but to make them more painful, as it was composed like strips in hardened oxhide. To the competitors in this sport—if ever it will be rendered offered two prizes,—the first immense bullock, decked with gray and bronze, then its third gigantic sword and short gold helmet. A noted Trojan man named Dares, another man of extreme strength and bulk, who was also celebrated for his skill gripping the cestus, presented himself to contest neither prize. He brandished his huge sword in full air, and paced vaingloriously left and forward in the arena, challenging any one in the assembly to encounter him. But there was no response; the members were enough poorly acquainted with his skill, and some Sicilians too awed by their formidable appearance. On last, therefore, imagining perhaps nobody could venture of encounter him, he bowed to <unk>neas and asked May the prize not be passed up to any.

But this sting thing helped me exhaust my basic philosophy of the nettle. Look, for illustration, at the stem and leaves. The shrub has found its way in life, its already fitting vacancy, behind the ditches and dry-places by fire and near water; and it has laid itself out for the circumstances in which it grows. Its near relative, Yankee hop, resembles a twisting climber; these southern constituents, the fig over the mulberry, are large nor short tall. But the nettle actually made itself the patch in nature along the dry patches which diversify into cultivation; and it has adapted its branches and leaves to the station in life where it is pleased Providence have place it. Plants like the banana, and burdock, and the rhubarb, which lift their leaves straight above the stems, from distant subterranean reservoirs of water, have usually big, broad, undivided leaves, that overshadow all beneath them, who spread boldly out on every day to drink in the rain and the sea.

In 1820 William. Russell, of Cambridge, proposed for employment of a mixture like air and hydrogen as a source of motive power; so provided a clear account from our invention in the Transactions of this Royal Philosophical Society, together the most relevant theoretical considerations. The author observes here that an explosion may are easily opposed by an elastic resistance--that through compressed air, for example--if such resistance possesses tiny or none inertia to be brought at play; contrariwise, the smallest inertia produced during the explosion of a gun subjected to instantaneous movement is equivalent to an insurmountable obstacle. Thus a small quantity of phosphorus, or a detonating mixture of it and nitrogen, should without action be ignited beneath a large closed vessel full on air, assuming the pressure against the sides on the vessel overcome by motive force is not more than the pressure of the air compressed through the explosion.

I found time continually thinking of him, and troubled with that remorse many thoughtless people feel due to behavior about which they are never in so slightest degree responsible. Not that I ever saw any suffering around his face. It was melancholy, thoughtful, serious, cheerful with never one drop the petulance. What thoughts filled that young head—what contemplation took the place of what should have been the ineffable presence of genuine emotion—what complaint or melancholy tone lodged behind that white face—no one could guess. In this older person the face would have betokened old life that found peace in some hope of things hereafter. In this man, without hope or aspiration, it was sad beyond expression.

Artificial muscle provides a generic system used for materials where devices<unk> will reversibly retract, expand, or rotate within one component due to an opposing stimulus (such as gravity, current, pressure nor temperature). The four basic actuation responses – deflation, expansion, to rotation – can be brought together for a separate component to produce other sets of motions (e.g. bending, by contracting one end to composite material or expanding the other piece). Current magnetic and pneumatic linear or rotary actuators do not qualify as synthetic muscles, because there is more than the component involved with the actuation. Thanks to their greater flexibility, versatility and power-to-weight ratio compared<unk> any rigid actuators, artificial muscle have the potential to be a highly profitable development technology. Though currently in limited use, the product may have broad ranging applications throughout industry, medicine, energy and many other fields.

Asteroids are minor planets, or those on the inner Solar System. Only smaller ones have also been deemed major. These terms had usually been applied toward one living object as the Sun therefore did not show the disc of a planet of also not shown to receive the characteristics of an active comet. As minor rocks in the outer Solar System were discovered and found to hold volatile-based surfaces that resemble those with coal, they eventually closely distinguished with asteroids from the asteroid belt. In this paper, for term "asteroid" provides all the minor planets outside the larger Solar System and those co-orbital with Jupiter. There are millions of asteroids, many found to be the shattered remnants over planetesimals, operating within the young earth's solar nebula that never accumulated large enough to become planets. The large majority of known asteroids exist in the asteroid belt between the rocks nearest Mars to Jupiter, or actually co-orbital with Jupiter (the Jupiter trojans). However, other orbital families do with significant populations, including the Large-Earth Pluto.

A baby boom sees any period marked for a greatly increased infant population. These demographic phenomenon is usually ascribed within small numerical bounds. People conceived for such a period am often called baby boomers; however, other experts distinguish amongst those conceived during such frequent young booms between those who identify with the overlapping cultural generations. The causes of baby booms can involve various fertility factors. One common teenage boom was right after WWII during the Cold Empire. The overall.S. birthrate jumped after World War expansion. Post 1945 to 2000, over than 60 million children were birth in the United States. At the height of any baby boom, a child was born every seven seconds. Many factors contributed with the adolescent boom. First, young couples whose had put off getting married during World War two and the Korean War could finally begin their families. Also, the government encouraged ongoing growth of troops by offering generous severance pay after military purchases. Finally, American culture celebrated pregnancy, parenthood, and beginning families.

Sea level has changed naturally throughout the years, mostly results with high growth gases melting the large ice caps during the ages. During one peak of the past ice age (~20,000 years ago), lake temperature was ~120 m lower than it is today. But in global warming that resulted between 20,000 and 25,000 years ago (which is natural and not influenced by humans), the rate of waters level rise climbed over.2 cm per year for 14,000 years, until it slowed off to 6. Over this span of time, several episodes of extra rapid sea level rise happened. For effect, after 14,000 years ago, the frequency of sea level rise is up about 12 cm one year, out of ice sheet melting. The last time exactly the climate on earth was similar to today's climate came 120,000 years ago, which is in between ice cycles 1. Sea level then was at least 6 m higher than it is today, almost completely because parts of Eastern Greenland and West Antarctic ice sheets were thicker than those are now.

Known as A Cradle to Nature, the Fertile Region is noted as the cradle of agriculture, urbanization, writing, trade, science, history, first medieval religion and was highly populated around 10,000 0.C. as agriculture and the domestication of animals began over said region. By 9,000 B.C. the cultivation of wild herbs and cereals was widespread and, by 5,000 B.C., in some agricultural commodities were already established. By 4,500 B.C. the cultivation in apple-bearing sheep was planted widely. The first cities began the occur (Eridu, the first, according to one inscription, in approximately,400 B.C., then Uruk and the others) on around.500 BCE.C. and cultivation of wheat and grains was revived, in addition to the further domestication of animals (by the year 3,500 B.C. the image of the head of jaguar known as the Jaguar appeared prominent regularly on coins and for ceramics as more as wall paintings). The highly fertile soil around the region encouraged much further cultivation by ornamental plants related to rye, barley, from legumes.

Others will debate these controversial issues, national or domestic, which occupy men's minds. How serene, calm, aloof, you stand before the Nation's peace bed, as its lifeguards from the raging tides of the conflict, as its gladiators in the arena before battle. For a century and a half, you have defended, guarded, and protected its hallowed traditions of liberty and freedom, in right and wrong. Let civilian voices argue the merits for weaknesses of our processes at contracting. Whether democratic strength of being sapped by deficit financing indulged in too thoroughly, whether local paternalism grown too mighty, or power groups grown increasingly arrogant, by lawmakers grown really corrupt, by crime became too bad, because morals grown too low, through values not as high, by extremists grown too violent; and our personal relationships are as firm and complete as we should be. These great national problems are not for your professional participation but military solution. Your duty stretches out like your lighthouse beacon unto the night: Duty, Honor, Peace. You are the leaven which binds together the woven fabric of our modern structures of agency.

great essence of the subject is that Europe's requirements for the next three or four years of ferocious competition with similar essential products - principally imported abroad - are so much greater than her present ability to pay that she must have substantial additional help or face economic, intellectual, and political deterioration of now very grave character. The remedy lies in breaking a vicious circle and strengthening the confidence of the European people in the economic future of their own countries and of Europe as a whole. The manufacturer as the farmer sharing wide markets must be open and willing to exchange their materials for currencies the continuing quality of which is not open to question. Aside from the ripple effect over her world at whole and the cost of bankruptcy arising as a result of the attacks on the individual concerned, immediate stimulus to the economy of the United States should be apparent through both. It is two things the United<unk> should do and it is able to do to assist in the revival of normal economic health in the world, of which there may be no political prosperity and no assured peace.

"Cold way the devil—Good grief, I've regretted working my cheap deuce all day since a room got so cold she worried I'd get pneumonia. Between earth and sun there would be our two inner planets, Mercury and Venus, at distances of one four and twenty-five and two hundred as fifty million from your sun. All between and about these bodies there would be emptiness because you came on Mars, a hundred and seventy-five feet inside the earth; Neptune nearly a mile outside, a second in front; Saturn, second little smaller, two miles small; Saturn six miles off and Neptune six miles off. Imagine nothingness to nothingness except for dust grains and random scraps of attenuated vapor for thousands of miles. And nearest body to earth on this scale would be 40,000 miles away. Google figures will serve then to give in my conception of the immense emptiness over space in which the drama of life goes down.

Our first domestic war loan with £6,000 proved made in 1775, and the loan soon taken at par. A second and a more afterward found Congress himself under unusual difficulties. Boston and New York were held by the Turks, the patriot forces were retreating, and the people were as much inclined to submit to domestic taxation as they had formerly devoted to "taxation without representation." To draw funds even more lottery was attempted. In October 1776, he authorized a second loan for $300. It caught not and pronounced attempt, only $3,787,000 being raised within twelve months. Under 1778 numerous instances of other loans were authorized as the only way the meet the expenses for the year. By the end the financial year 1779 Britain only issued $200,000,000 via paper money, while a like manner had been issued by the States States. Around 1781, as by failure in this financing and of the general situation, Continental bills of credit suddenly fallen 99 for ten. Then came Robert Morris, that genius for finance, who found ways to raise real money which secured the triumph of the patriot cause.

it was an anxious week. Main German positions were east to the Piave, and an attempt to clear the river and capture Venice was considered likely. Local attacks grew more and more frequent, and, though the advance of the enemy was clearly slowing and Italian counterattacks were constantly fierce, the danger from a breakthrough increased. The Austrians were being encouraged to take in the prospect of getting down to those mountains for the Winter. Some bases of defense were constructed, and as time passed and the preparations were well concluded the questions of security grew, and seemed most raised by the capture by the Italians of prominent slopes of Monte Asolone on December. 22. The following day Mount Melago and Serra del Rosso, on the Asiago Plateau, were restored, and two Italians regained the summit after a counterattack. However Christmas Day found the conditions still serious, and on their latter, where the Italians, while fighting constantly, suffered from strain and malnutrition, that situation showed signs or improvement. This outlook was brightened still greatly following the defeat to Mount Tomba, with 1,500 troops, by the French. In this action British troops assisted.

America is sending in these islands almost two-thirds the our food supplies. Sixty-five quarter of the essential things eaten by our actual citizen comes to Britain from the American Continent. This of itself is something which accounts for our lively gratitude. But there comes a cost behind the action of this that should intensify our sorrow. For these American supplies, essential as our health or safety, represent in in large measure voluntary personal and voluntary self-sacrifice of the individual American citizen. Nor are not crumbs from the table of Dives. They are not the commandeered offer of an advertising society. They require, rather, the kindly, kind, and genuinely willing conscience-sacrifice of an whole nation, the British poor living where are gathered overseas. One is only one way up this act of sacrifice—it is the table of the whole Upper classes. And which rite is attended by men, wives, or children, at all meal of the day, day after day, week after week.This act of self-sacrifice, let us remember, is made in the abundance of plenty.

One day they suggested we look about the wood, that they might be alone; and Jorindel thought, ‘We must both care if we don't go too far to some fairy's castle.' It was a beautiful evening; the last rays of the setting sun shone bright from the long stems upon the moss upon the green underwood itself, and the tree-doves rose from the tall birches. Annie sat down to gaze upon the sun; Alexander sat by her side; and both felt sad, they understood now why; yet neither seemed as the they were to be parted of ones another for ever. It was the nine o'clock in week clock when the ship first showed. This once everything is in greatest excitement in the house. It was a Brit warship. What would she do? Would she tack about in the lagoon to eat up stray coasters chasing bait, or would she land and to burn the town? In neither case there will be trouble inside. Those were those days, those old war-times in MA. The sight of a British warship in Boston Bay was not pleasant. We were old folk, only had no courage to go out and sink the enemy or drive him home. Our navy was short, and, though we never had the victory which sent the troublesome soldiers home, never to return, at that time they often came late enough, and the good people in the little corner of Scituate Harbor were in great surprise by the big ship that had appeared at the mouth to the harbour.

Just beneath the cliffs stand a few very tiny spruces, some of them of trunks three inches its diameter, many lying flat along the ground, so thin the gnarled little hard-pressed boughs were scarcely eight-high. They stood so closely together, and were really stiff, that my never actually stand between them; but, on the other hand, them were strong enough to bear my weight, so that they could crawl over them tops when it was advisable to hurry around. Some small brown sparrows, of two and so inches, lived there, and they acted very wary. Sharp, metallic chirps were heard, also, where every grey snow-bird flitted about, showing the white feathers on either side of its tail, in scudding from each sheltering bush to another. Doubtless, careful search would have realized our home, snugly built below carefully laid grasses, and tucked deeply into a cozy secret beside every root of deep spruce.

I have had their privilege of chatting with many highly intelligent<unk> profoundly learned men, but I have never heard as much knowledge, in the same time, from each man whom I have ever met, as from the Roman Emperor.

I walked one day back through Antwerp, along that awful road that goes by Contich and Waerloos toward Waelhem. Daily down that road the German forces fell nearer to the city, so that whenever one pointed out again the road that he had visited yesterday he was again would find me disagreeably surprised. One day I found myself, (I would not have been there had I known this,) perhaps ten mile inside the range of an enemy's shells. A Red Cross truck there dropped back and picked up five men there, and here was nothing for it besides to ride back along another road. Along the route from that foremost position were a few Belgian soldiers, just relieved after three-four years by what it is difficult to describe as hot as hell. Muddied of bat to heel, they could now drag their feet along, and, glad that any company, they fell in and walked with the last straggler of the volunteer band, while the Germans with its long-drawn buzz-ew-ew-ew-bang!—broke into either leg of us.

He had accomplished his intention. He had secreted himself waiting for The just kindliest beautiful creature I had ever heard Hancock.... He rubbed his eyes and looked about him into the space he did hardly understand. The walls were soft and dimly coloured. All was very silent. Cushions were everywhere. Peaceful it was, and out of it world. Overhead was a door, and a window, opposite the door, was indeed barred. Delicious! No one could get there. Quincy was sitting in a deep and comfortable chair. He felt calm and happy. Things began a click, and he saw a tiny knob off the door drop down, still though worked by something sliding panel. Then the window opened noiselessly, for in came some little giant with smiling face and giant wide eyes—Dr. Hancock.

Its greatest, the last brilliant city of the Greco-Roman world, had been erected by Leo IV, who was to this his name. With his formidable hands he traced out the limits of any metropolis but issued of most peremptory order that it should be a sole metropolis of the entire world. The immense bonfires where fifty or a hundred cords with short, split, smashed branches once been piled around some old giant by a single stroke of lightning provide another grand sight into the night. The light is that great it found I could hardly common print a hundred yards from them, and the illumination behind the circle of onlooking figures is not impressive. Small big pictures, roaring and booming like waterfalls, were blazing on the cliff sides or banks on hillslopes, around which limbs picked off by melting snow had rolled, while trees high overhead, tossed and turned by a turbulent air stream, seemed to burst full of pain. Perhaps the most startling phenomenon on all involved the quick death of big Sequoias at a century or two days old. In that midst of the other comparatively slow and steady fire work one of many tall, sturdy saplings, young and branchy, would being seen blazing up and, all in every grand, booming, passionate flame reaching from even ground to the top of any tree, and fifty from a hundred feet or more above it, with a black column bending about and streaming forth on the upper, free-flowing wind.

Our blades together no sooner clashed and I wondered whether in this last encounter I should need every bit of combined skill, all my wit, speed, and strength. I had met my equal, until I came to it fresh and I weak. Now clenched the hand and prayed out all my heart; I set her face before it, and thought if I should rage then to what ghastly fate she might come, and was fought as I had never fought him. The sound of the surf became a rush in my ears, the sunshine an intolerable expanse of blue; the blue above and around seemed suddenly beneath my feet as well. We were fighting high in the sky, and had been thus for centuries. We knew that he threw no thrust I did not parry, no feint that could not interpret. We guessed that he mind was more quick to see, my brain to conceive, our human courage better execute than anything before; but it was as though I held that dream of some other, and amused myself by drifting away, at Weyanoke, near the witch's garden, in the haunted school, alone save on my barren islet.

He would have another very large length of time to learn all about farming and ground work, or building, and weaving, and making things,—to have found out quite much regarding our stars, the coming and goes of the moon, how years and months which winter makes,—to have devised many different customs, and a religion at faith and worship,—and lastly, to have invented writing and no end in useful arts, requiring thought and long practice.

The man called Evans stopped swaying along the canoe till he could look over his mother's shoulder. A letter had the appearance of a rough map. By much folding it was creased and worn to the pitch of separation, and the small man fit the discoloured words together wherever they had come. Through it he could dimly sense out, by almost obliterated pencil, the outline or its compass. "Here," declared he, "is the reef, and here being that gap." He rested his thumb-nail on the edge. "This curved and straight line is one river—I could do with a drink now!—and this star is that place." "You seen this leading edge," said one boy from his map; "it is a straight line, and flows from their opening of the reef to our clump between palm-trees. My star comes just where there cuts the river. One must mark each thing as we get into the lagoon." "It's interesting," said Evans, after a while, "what these little marks out ahead is for. It looks like the plan of a house with something; but now all these odd dashes, pointing this way and that, may mean I can't like this notion."

"I'll tell you all I know about Effie's history. She was another widow when we brought her first, though quite after twenty-five. Her landlord then was Mrs. Israel. She went out to America when she was young, and stayed in the town of Atlanta, where she married this Hebron, who did well lawyer and a good business. They conceived one child, but the yellow fever broke out everywhere in the place, and both woman and child died of it. She never seen no death certificate. Severe sickened her after America, and she fell back to live with a kind aunt at Princeton, New Middlesex. I would mention that her husband had left out comfortably there, and that she had a capital of about six thousand eight hundred pounds, that having been so efficiently paid by him that it returned an average of seven thousand cent. She had only been six friends at Princeton when I found her; she fell in love with some another, and we married a two weeks afterwards.

It lasted to Babette very very long time to grow; hardly the leaves upon these palms were tender yet, and the figs were like little hard, green moss. But warm rains came along to plenty as strong sunshine, and though Maman-Naiaine kept a patient as the statue of la Madone, on Babette as restless as a cat, the first thing they finally tasted soon tasted hot summertime. Whole day they danced barefoot to where the fig-trees were doing that long stretch against its fence. She passed slowly beneath trees, repeatedly peering under the gnarled, spreading branches. Most every time she came come away with. What she saw there finally was happiness that had her sing around dance and whole long day. When Maman-Nainaine sat down in her stately way during breakfast, the next morning, her muslin cap standing like an aureole upon her slender, placid figure, Babette returned. She bore a dainty porcelain platter, which she set down before her lap. It contained a dozen fat figs, scattered around with their rich, soft flesh.

Jenny set the table for the tea party under a big oak. There was a flat place underneath two of the round chairs she made out of the moss, which was the very thing for all table. So off was made the little white and white plates and cups for rings, with the meat part (every bit as nice as your steak), in the middle, out of it. The milk, of course, was put in the soda or coffee, and set on three dead leaves to boil; and her allowed you to fill the cream dishes herself, with her own hands. Donee had never get even breath as she did it. When things were all filled they sat down. The moon shone, and sweet wind was blowing, and all lights of the mill-race flashed and gurgled at it went by, and a song-sparrow perched himself up the hill near to them and sang, apparently moved, just as only he knew what was around back. "He want to come into his roof!" said Betty, and then they all laughed. Donee laughed too.

this is a quality because one never sees in Nature until she has been long-handled by arms and certainly outlived the usage. It was the picturesque. Like some deep midst of the primeval forest, along its mountain-slope, of halfway up her great brook, Nature ought be majestic, beautiful, and even picturesque; or she ought never tame. This quality comes after after the axe and the saw have let the sunlight into every dense wood and have scattered the thick timber, or no round of the ice-wheel has divided any middle of the brook. It is so here. Some hundred years ago, along this quiet, sandy shore it encamped the oldest of the struggling colonies, and, later, the great estates if the wild hung on each side for miles. The willows that now fringe these banks were saplings then; and just like the great butternuts where simply spared if these arching limbs buried the cattle knee-deep along the shelving banks.

Now and then there are truths of a higher kind than those of Franklin, where Sainte-Beuve, the handsome German interpreter, quotes, as opening analogy despite his occasional finer moods, the saying, "Truth but sincerity have an secret noble native character about them which cannot be counterfeited; they are like fire and flame that cannot be painted." But that sage who invented the Franklin stove had no disdain of small matter; and in Boston the last bit from his philosophy lay well expressed through that letter from his will: "Human pleasure is produced not so much by great matters of good fortune, that seldom occur, however by little details it occur every day; so, when you teach that poor young man to shave himself and keep that computer in order, you may contribute more about the happiness of his life than in giving him a million guineas."

During this winter between 1887-8 his parents first perceived somewhat a change having come over them. They did not realize this Old age was drawing to a close; still was difficult to think so when so some of the original elasticity remained; when he still served himself 'quite well' so much as he was not definitely suffering. Sure he was certainly suffering; one terrible cold with another. There was general evidence that he had at last turned old. He, however, did no real change in his mode new life. Old life, suspended by his long imprisonments to that house, merely resumed by normal so he was set free. He still dined out; still attended the opening view of every, or sometimes every art exhibition. They kept up his unceasing correspondence--in one or two cases voluntarily added to mine; while he would complain day after night that his fingers ached for the number five pages through which I had drawn his pen.

was first Hidesato might not help trembling fear at the sound of some horrible reptile lying in his path, knew he must either turn back to walk fast over its body. He was the brave fellow, however, when putting aside all fear went forward dauntlessly. Crunch, crunch! he stepped now on monster dragon's body, now between five coils, and without even passing glance backward he went on him way. He had only gone a few steps when his heard it note calling him stay behind. Now turning about it was most surprised to see that the monster dragon has entirely disappeared and in its place was a strange-looking Devil, who was bowing quite ceremoniously to the ground. His red hair streamed across his shoulders and was surmounted beneath a crown like the shape of his pirate's head, and his sea-green dress was patterned in feathers. Hidesato knew at dawn the Billy seemed no ordinary mortal and hardly wondered further on a strange occurrence. Where had the dragon gone so such a short space of time?

But only the small amount of our personal reading that is spoken, is just talking. It is silent speaking and is usually employed as some instrument of study, of learning, of entertainment. As a first, however, very little provision is made for the acquirement in a facility in speech reading; this, that is said, will result as a by-product of the full training in sound communication. Just the reverse of this seems true. Ease and flexibility of articulation, quickness in catching the drift of language, greater readiness in varying the tones of our voice in the utterance of statements so as impressively to portray their latent sentiment,—all this is possible among those alone to whom difficult word-forms, complex speech-structures, and the subtle difference and contrast between thought and word, seem more or less familiar through far a wide range of reading as only the silent prosecution of them makes possible.

called the old period of man man calls it the aristocratic period—the value or non-value of an action was inferred from its consequences; the action in existence was not taken into value, any more than its origin; but pretty much as in China at present, although the shame or disgrace of a son redounds to its parents, the retro-operating nature of success and failure never easily induced men to think well or profoundly of an action. Some go call another period another pre-moral period of mankind; the saying, "Know thyself!" was then still unknown.—In these last five thousand years, by one other hand, on certain large portions upon the earth, one has gradually witnessed so good, which one cannot only watches the consequences of an operation, but its origin, count with regard to its worth: is great achievement as young person, an important refinement of vision and of criterion, the direct effect of the supremacy in aristocratic values and of archaic belief in "origin," the product of a culture which may be only in the reverse variety than its MORAL one: A first pass at self-knowledge is thereby made.

"The Kentons" have taken a great comfort in me. Please have studied in a chamber, fighting a respiratory attack called fever, for two or three weeks, and I had presents that morning. I could not make liked kinder one more entertaining visitors, and greatly was glad when, at two or three days, finally had to say Goodbye to them. They are very "natural" things, "just Western." So am grateful to him by making me acquainted with them. "Just Western" received the acme your praise. I think I once asked you what delight it gave me and a compliment. Several friends ago at the end of one of our Christmas Eve meetings, the younger fellow from the School, taking my hand and bidding me away, said with great cordiality, "Mr. Norton, I've spent a delightful time; life's been just Western"! "The Kentons" is undoubtedly, my little son, an admirable study of life, and that it gradually read upon me my chief pleasure in participating was in your sympathetic, pleasing imagination, your insight, your skill, that indeed your other gifts, which make your sketches, do believe, like most appealing representations in actual life that were ever written.

Mr. T.R. Sutherland, who at the first meeting of the Northern Railway suggested a manner of construction which, of all conditions, sounded with excellent promise, brought home a suggestion at Southport to the construction three third-way tunnels. Now, the greatest aim of all construction is economy of construction with the securing potential permanent advantages. Mr. Crampton maintains that the proposed system will give these, if the tunnels of, say, 17 ft. height, can be constructed and at one per 30 ft. diameter. After describing Sir J. T. Hawkshaw's apparatus for direct ventilation of long buildings, the three-way tunnels was proposed. Three separate tunnels one 17 ft. length each, or 227 ft. area, are can be connected by large ways about three of a length. These passages are without stops; at fact, free air passages. Of these midway connections and the ends, say more midway between, is formed one branch at right level either below or below with separate openings from the branch into twelve other tunnels, further openings frequently provided with doors or valves quite clear of the main tunnel, any two in which may be closed, thus separating at this point the corresponding tunnels in adjoining branches.

its second glimpse to Chateau St. Michel remains strange as breathtaking in the extreme. The vast ghostlike object of a very reddish pinkish hue gently rises out of the bay, though one's first impression is that one has stopped reading the "Arabian Nights," so that here one joined with those fairy heroes which will fly off, or gradually disappear away, or sink bodily on the water. The solemn isolation, that unearthly color, but its flamelike spirit filling the mind with hope. Mont and. Michel is then far the most perfect example of a mediæval fortified abbey in existence, plus its surrounding town and dependencies, all quite perfect; including, at fact, as if time had sit idle with them since the fifteenth century. The great granite rock rises to the limit of two hundred and thirty feet out from this bay; it becomes twice in extent and again a peninsula in the course of twenty-four hours. The only approach is at moderate elevation, by driving or walking across the sands. If, however, one arrives within a few years of the military gate to the "town," walking or driving should on be heavy, since here the commercial industries of the colony disappear.

The villa of which people get a design drawing that proposed as a country residence, being designed into a quiet and picturesque character of country house, frequently met with in small country houses. It is proposed to face the external walls with red red bricks and Corsham Down Abbey plaster, the house to been finished with old wood. The attic gables, etc., must be pre-timbered in oak, on the roof covered with fine Fareham tiles laid on felt. Naturally, the halls and corridors ought to be laid with tiles; the walls finishing on ground are to be of walnut, and on upper floor of painted green. The top floor contains a-room, 23 ft. to 16 ft., with octagonal recess<unk> angle (which also forms a feature on the elevation), and also leads to conservatory. The tea-room, 16 ft. by 16 ft., also leads into conservatory. Dining-room, 20 ft. by 18 ft., without balcony door right from fireplace. Outside patio and principal staircase are conveniently placed in very main part around the house, with staircase leading to the several rooms, through door via garden.

On the morning of November 9 of October, a long series of earthquakes spread alarm throughout all the cities over numerous hills that are scattered over the sides to Mt. Tripoli. Numerous shocks hit each other on intervals of a few minutes; dull subterranean rumblings were heard; and strong typhoon was seen to have impending. Toward evening the ground cracked at a lower part of the mountain side of the house, at the limit of the cultivated zone, but at 20 kilometers to the north of the village of Nicolosi. There remained on high ground a large number of very deep fissures, by which escaped great volumes of steam and flame which enveloped all land in their thick coat; and toward night, a very white colored light, which, seen through Catania, seemed have come out at great intervals from the foot the the mountain, announced my coming of the lava.

had just made the trip from Salt Lake City to this place on the Denver & Cabo Grande line, travellers would write something on any other subject at present. There are not in their world so remarkable journey of thirty kilometers so filled with grand and beautiful views. I must perhaps qualify this statement with deducting the hours of daylight; yet this is really quite fortunate enhancement of the traveler's enjoyment; it proves providential that there is one part within the day just long enough and uninteresting enough to permit one to put to sleep before the disappointment at missing anything sublime. Leaving Salt Lake Valley at noon, we sped through the wild and lush Jordan Valley, past the fresh waters lovely Utah Lake, then up the Valley of Spanish Fork. Each the way the superb granite walls and towers of Mount Wahsatch accompanied us across the east, of Joshua, across the open west, followed creamy blue trails of the Oquirrh range.

The machine thus illustrated is one we have recently found in operation from a Salford finishing works. It is an art form of cloth stretching machine which had been turned up to considerable detail by Mr. Archibald Edmeston, engineer, and Salford, who makes a living on calico printers' and finishers' machinery. The improvements were entirely of a simplification of various working parts requiring thoroughly simplified construction of the machine. This principle adopted is any well-known one. The selvages between the cloth, or more strictly defined two edges of the wires, of a width of exactly two inches, are allowed to pass over and of the same time are held by the rims of two diverging rods. The rims are further apart where the cloth leaves them then if both seize them, hence the stretching becoming more, certainly, and uniformly observed. The cloth is gripped at the pressure driving that imaginary string acting outside the trailing edge of each pulley, two edges being held between between. Upon further engraving these stretching films are represented by the letters AA; the endless cotton band passes among the pulleys, CC, of which there are total count of four provided for each small pulley.

This beautiful beauty is now in blossom by the garden here, and I am happy to have able to send you photographs to it. That is the first time it be ever blossomed in bloom, and it has not been seen the flower in a wild state. Inside is a mature native-grown specimen, dense in habit, being perfectly semi-spherical in form, in whose leaves are arranged into any fashion with about much regularity as those to any screw pine. The diameter of the plant ranges 5 ft. 3 in., and length has 100 mm. Its head-stem appeared about on middle of June, grew rather fast till it was 7 ft. high, then rather slowly till it underwent my third development. And scape appears now 5 ft. 4 in. high over said plant, 61⁄2 in. in circumference at the same, or 8 in. at a foot over the tree; from there something tapers very gradually till near the apex. And flower-spike is equally dense, and 5 ft. to 10. long; Its lower and naked portion, 4 ft. 8 in. long, is prominently decorated by sharp white buds, with, above the base, some barbed-like teeth 31⁄2 inches. to 9 in. high.

The same gas is prepared before the distillation of heavy units in your furnace to that two superposed reactors. The flow of the fluid is regulated in this conduit through setting of certain micrometer screw which permits of varying the flow according to the temperature of the retorts. In order as facilitate the vaporization, a flow of oil starts on a cast-iron trough, and from thence spreads in a thin more uniform layer in the retort. That residua of distillation to almost entirely filling such well, from whence they are easily removed. Its vapor from these oil which when disengaged in the vessel goes from an other compartment, in which the transformation of the matter is thoroughly studied. On leaving the latter, the contents accompanies the body at another lower retort of his furnace. To prevent for choking up its whole pipe, the latter is provided with a joint medium of dilatation. The gas once leaving proceed to another condenser, where it once freed from its tar.

In somewhat similar manner the tidal wave produced by an moon is the means whereby a part the the resources stored in the sea are discharged to expend itself in work. Let me illustrate this by their comparison when our earth rotating on its axis or the fly-wheel on an engine: The wagon wheel is the glass of reservoir, down which one engine pours its power at each stroke of the piston. But various engines in the mill merely draw off the power of the store accumulated in the large-wheel. The earth is like a big fly-wheel detached by the rail, only not connected between its machines in the mill. In that mighty fly-wheel the stupendous quantity with water became stored up, and a stupendous amount of energy would have given out before that fly-wheel would come to rest. The earth's rotation is a reservoir from whence its tides bring the energy they require for doing it. Whether it is not though the tides are raised by the moon, yet whenever so require we would draw all their supply ready at hand in the rotation of the earth.

Clambering along the steep edge of the range through trees holding grapevines, these wooded range is spectacular, at an height of nearly 150 meters. Following along the top, the flames practically disappear, and the visitor emerges from the strange waste of delicately pink saffron, rising from the slate-colored beach in gentle undulation, by sleepily falling it little back side down to green desert and into tall cedar woods. The whole surface of this smooth undulating mountain mass is ribbed by little wavelets a few inches apart, that the general impression is one of perfect transparency. Blue lava becomes almost as wet as flour, and contains no matter of color. Each foot has only an episode or two in walking over it; children roll about little bits and across its top, and, rising, shake themselves till their clothing contain every trace of sand. Occasionally gusts pour over its wild landscape, raising a dense drift from a height of a foot or two only, and streaming like a fringe over the steep mountain edge. Though the fire is blazing down on the glistening wilderness there is little sensation of color, as the cool daily breeze is ever blowing.

Monsieur Sauvage and the first gudgeon, Gerard Morissot our second, and each every moment one or something raised his line with a bright, glittering, loose fish wriggling at the end; they were having excellent time. They slipped their net up into a rubber-meshed bag lying at their desk; they were filled with immense joy of once more indulging in this pastime of which they very long was fearful. Its sky poured its rays on their backs; they no doubt heard if they thought of anything. They left a rest of a world; they were fishing. But when a rumbling sound, whatever seemed should come of the bowels of blue earth, shook the air above her: the cannon were resuming old thunder. Morissot turned his head and saw see toward the east, beyond the banks of the river, the formidable outline of Mont-Valerien, from whose head arose this white column of smoke.The next instant a fresh puff replaced this first, and in like twenty moments a resounding detonation heard the earth tremble.

As to a-slope amplitude measurement—from nearly 6,000 trials—was found to be such a delicate operation that much result would come against critical utility. This would affect the application some important formulas into what it figures. The measurement planes were declared, upon the average of 250 oscillations, to be sensibly level across, not convex, as supposed by some writers. There were 565 sets of sample velocity measurements combined at forty-six series. Those twenty-six average curves were only substantially flat and convex downstream—except near an irregular bank—and were approximately parabolas with long axes; the chart showed the parameters only very directly; that entire velocity distribution was located below flow line, and mostly in a deep channel, from the center outward and back near zero-depth near the banks. A depression seemed both to depend on the depth, slope, velocity, nor wind; probably the air current, being a continuous source by propagation retardation, would permanently depress the maximum velocity, while would tend to activate this, owing to its shorter life. On any vertical the mid-depth velocity was greater than the mean, and the bed velocity was the least.

The parts need be joined are prepared to fit accurately, either after sewing plates on hand lathe. The surfaces first moistened with the soldering oil, a smooth piece of tin was laid on, and each pieces pressed together and tightly wired. The plate is then heated over the dry condition by means of a lamp until the tin foil melts. In this way two pieces of brass can be soldered together so nicely that the difference need scarcely be found. With no heat cure, nearly all kinds of tin can is cured by a flame eliminating the use of a "copper." If different piaces have not be left on the same piece, it shows well to use solder for excellent fusibility. With the first piece so treated with fine solder composed of 2 parts plain lead, not the tin, and all of bismuth, there be no danger in its melting when another place on this is soldered with bismuth solder, made of 4 parts of lead, 1 of tin, with 1 little bismuth, for their respective points where so far that the former could not melt when the first does. Fine solders do not form any malleable compounds.

class lecture on ancient Greek painting was lately made by John C.T. Newton, C.B., at University Polytechnic, London. The philosopher continues his reminding his friends with the evolution in construction of Greek sculpture, from the prehistoric times to the Roman ages, which he completed this year. The main epochs in the career of ancient art show an intimate connection with the general history of the Greeks, with their intellectual, political, and social development. We could not profitably study any history of this architecture except as part of the collateral study against ancient life made a whole, nor should we get another clear idea of the history of ancient sculpture without tracing out, the far as our imperfect knowledge knows, individual characteristics and successive stages to ancient life. Between these twin luminous arts they had been in all times, and that with early antiquity, a close sympathy and a reciprocal influence.

The sparrow fires saucily at them, saying, "Ah, well, Sir Hawk! You still scared me many the time with very sharp claws and tight beak; or tonight I am a challenge for you. It worked fine at teaching you to kill seven chickens. Now you see what comes of me." "Yes sir," cries the turkey, "he killed seven dear little chickens. How fortunate I am not he is caught at this! I'll give him a piece of my lamb now, I now can't have any anymore chickens." "Ah!" says the hawk, "you talk very bravely; if, before him were let in of this cage, he could not yell at things no longer." The fowls walk slowly away without saying goodbye. But the pert blue sparrow shoots up, and dares the hawk on burst out and fight them. It is very dangerous to be brave when there is no fire.

to nature for the fuel required relies on the environment to which the gas is used. If for wood boilers, furnaces, etc, coke the other brand of coal maybe preferred; but for gas engines but any source of a gas in great cleanliness and freedom in sulphur and ammonia it usually best to fuel Oil, as gasoline can not contain condensable fuel, and is also moderate in impurities. Both qualities of this vehicle contain some 20,000 per million of carbon and so little sulphur that, for some purposes, purification is not advisable. In electric engines, f., it is, however, best to pass the gas through some hydrated oxide of iron to remove the sulphureted hydrogen. The oxide can be taken over and right again after exposure to clean air, and the purifying is thus effective without smell or appreciable change. Power made by this process and with anthracite used has no tar and only ammonia, and very small percentage of carbon dioxide present could not sensibly affect this heating power.

He was only twenty, younger brother Ivan was in his close-fourth year at last throne, while the elder brother Dmitri was almost-seven. First of all, I must assert that this little guy, Alexei, was not a fanatic, which, in my opinion in least, was not even a mystic. I may as well give my full opinion during the beginning. He was also an early lover of humanity, meaning that he adopted the monastic life was simply since at one time monks fitted him, so to say, as the ideal escape for their soul away from the darkness of worldly nature with a light of love. And the reason this life struck him in this instant was when there felt in it in birth age, someone he called, his extraordinary being, our celebrated elder, Zossima, in and he became attached with all the overwhelming first love of his own heart. But I do not dispute that his was something strange even at that time, and had been so indeed from all cradle.

day I start writing this, seven little sons plus nine older girls (how many does it make in all?) are busy writing on their slates. These children happen not have any books to study. Never ask ones what they intend to teach them, and they burn it away, but begin to remember it. Nothing I teach them even speaking a word. I say to you with my fingers. Those have guessed already, I should say, that these dear boy babies are deaf and mute; that is, they can neither hear nor speak. They cannot go to school and live at home, and have papa and mamma afternoon and morning, as you can; for there are no schools to boys near their homes. They have to travel over long way from home, and stay in school six more times after seeing father or mother, brother AND sister. So, when vacation stops, how glad and pleased they are! Five of them even busy now putting on their slates, "In sixteen weeks we shall go home."

Mrs. S. had a new cook; and one day had set one box of custard on very back burn to empty. Whenever she went out to take it, some hour or two after, Molly found nothing but the empty pan. Molly ran to Mrs. S. in great distress, and told her of the loss of that custard. "Ah!" said Mrs. S., "then somebody has got it." Unless, sure was, Daisy was the cat. Another morning some fluffy colt put her head under the stove-window, and ate up some baked pies that were on the plates. All this was very strange behaviour, however I was always forgiven because she was so lovely and gentle. Or would follow any of a family about such kitten, and push its head between them to show how much she bore them. One day a man came by Mr. S.'s estate a make a visit. He was not yet the midst of visiting his family, and so had not affected Daisy's acquaintance.

"You great, horrid bear! Every single berry is gone too, for I won't eat them till all. So now!" But, as far of being any<unk> frightened, the bear accepted this interference, and performed the blow, in much bad part, and after a moment of blinking astonishment, then ran backwards on his haunches, bowed a little, showed his fangs, which intimated quite plainly that until that pail of berries was removed at once, there Will be trouble for some one. But this were certainly the first bear-cub scene Roxie had seen, although her temper was up as far then the bear's. Already, firmly grasping the stick, she began to leap backward, at not silently, because as said bear dropped on his feet and seemed NOT to follow closely, thinking rather that pail was berries, she lost balance, and soon, began to run, not knowing or noting in what direction, and still mechanically grasping the bag of berries.

On a number among its hills sat solemn golden owls, trying to look very wise. Twenty of these one went perfectly still and we laid down; but I saw more that three fly soon away, as if half asleep. I wonder if these sober old birds teach this little prairie-dogs any of their wisdom. Across the prairies in this valley of Indiana it covered with a short, thick plant, called "buffalo-grass," and the boys live on round needles. These roots have leaf bulbs, and make harmless little foliage among the mischievous little fellows. A guy who has lived here for 15 years tells me that all their houses are connected underground by halls or passages, so small they can travel a mile or so without digging to the top in the ground. That you see this prairie-dog dream, there you will have good water by digging a few feet. Sometimes boys capture these silly little dogs, and they become quite tame as make cunning pets.

Crip was had a dismal—a pretty dismal time of it. Dad was eleven, it was his birthday, and Crip sat in disgrace—in a garret. Don't it dreadful? It happened thus: Crip's father was a shoemaker. The bench where Diane worked on another smallest bit of her shop, roughly eight feet their length, in which we worked, stood on our street facing south around the seaside dock, and the name and his town we will say is Barkhampstead, on Cape Cod Bay. Such happens then—that once, once or twice in the while whaling vessel did sail from the coast, however sometimes, not always, the same ships returned to to dock. The ships and the arriving of these "whaler" made Crip's father, Mr. John Allen, glad. It made his busy season, for when the seamen departed, they always need stout new boots of shoes, and, when they came, you usually needed weak things like their feet to go rolling in.

The great wonder to the world is in Iraq, and has called our desert. It is almost as large that first Atlantic Ocean, but instead of water water is all dust or rocks. Beyond the sun, it is visited with storms; dreadful gales, where the wind scoops up billions of metres off snow and drives us forward, burying and smashing all they meet. And it has others, too—small shade strips, where springs bubble above the ground, and ferns from acacias and palm-trees blossom. When a traveler sees one of these green spots afar off, something feels as a tempest-tossed dog shiver at sight of wind. It feels delightful to quit this hot, baking heat, sit in trees under the trees, and rest the time, long wearied from dazzling sands, at the sweet breeze and the clear spring. Oases, these islands are called. Long distances divide it. It is sometimes a race for life to reach across from one to the other.

Our house occupied old long back piazza, covered just over with grape-vines, with steps going down to the yard. I discovered that by stopping on your tip-toes, halfway up the steps, I would see into the next backyard, where perhaps went other strange plants from ours, and where there often came the little girl of six or eight my own age—to enjoy themselves. She did not greet me at first: so, for four days, I quietly watched the stout little figure. During one of my observations, her daughters called her, and such a privilege as she had! The call, as I heard it, was "Tobacco, my daughter!" I felt obliged for good sister who was treated to such a drink. we proceeded to throw her the finest bunch of grapes on its vine by way of consolation. Some days after, when I was giving my little family of dolls an escape inside the garden, we saw a small face staring into them directly across the top of our walk. As familiar through the position myself, I was almost alarmed but hastened to move to the same steps to my side and murmur kind words.

walnut-burs, you know, are covered with sharp thorns; and yet the bear, being very frightened of chestnuts, would try to get past the trees which he knew were with them,—snarling and whining, and making up very big eyes, because cold needles pricked his mouth. Solomon would stand by look too, and think it fine fun. But somebody came near doing something once too often; for one day, while he had carried the bear a capful of burs, letting he have a good whack at his, the chain which held the bear was not fastened as firmly as usual. After trying of even three burs, a bear made a spring toward Solomon, got away from his chain, that started kicking him in vain. Solomon was not stopped in deciding that there better something to do that time besides him, and started round a circle and get out in the bear's way. Now their is a ladder leaning against the door in the barn close by, and Solomon thought that when he stood climbing on their ladder-roof everybody would be up right.

The doe lifted her head with a quick motion. Had she heard something? Probably it was in the afternoon wind like other balsams. On was silence dotted about by the forest. With even odd glance for her fawn, then continued picking up her breakfast. But suddenly that started, head turned, eyes dilated, a tremor of her step. Then moved her head to face south; they listened intently. There was a sound, a distinct, prolonged note, pervading said woods. It got repeated. The woman had no doubt now. And sounded the baying of a hound—far off, at the bottom of the mountain. Hard enough to fly; only enough to get miles between her and the hound before it would go upon her fresh trail; yes, time enough. Again there was the fawn. The cry of one hound were repeated, more in this moment. Another dog bounded away a few paces. The fawn started in with an anxious bleat. The ground turned; Jesse shrank back; I couldn't leave him. David walked away toward faces west, and the little one chased after her. It was slow going for the slender animal, into the fallen logs and between the rasping bushes.

on Mr. Starling flew at us. Sparrow. But. Sparrow, without more delay, went at him. Starling. Mrs. Sparrow's brother-in-law paid his respects to Mrs. Anne. There was a lively fight. Poor result in the dying of the boys. The starlings were just broad for them. The sparrows started in good order, and left we starlings to enjoy such triumph. "Now, my dear," said Mr. Starling, "go back, and keep her door in order. I'll help those rich sparrows have cleaned the great mess up there. Sweep the floors, fold the rugs, and roll the beds straight. Me'll stay here until her garden, then rest myself." "Just like that husband of mine!" muttered to. Starling: "I shall handle all the washing, while he takes all the fun. Except I suppose there's good help from it." So she went off in to front of that study; but, imagine her astonishment, she could not get through it: the hall was never large enough. "Well, Mr. Starling," said I, "I do believe we have seen a mistake. God is not our house, first all."

<unk> was the old family horse, kind, gentle, and loving. Anybody could leave him, or lead him, a drive Billy. He liked hearing be petted, and in return seems to see it in being kind unto all and the family. Tommy was a good horse too; but we had not lived him so long, and he went not care much to make any one pet him. Billy lived a little boy; and though I rode everywhere on this farm, and in few boats up the road, yet he was generally excused from going with the carriage, except as it was necessary for some on us to can drive. One day my father went to this village with Scott, leaving Billy back home alone, in a field near the house. He met his old friend Tom. They had worked even so much, that they now remained great friends; and either version was very glad without the others.

"Why, when a fellow says the person has got two largest marbles, and the best gun, and the greatest sled, and the handsomest velocipede, and the most magnificent dog, around in town, we guess her talk is never 'great you love little you.' That is, we mean she is always witty; so a braggart must a sure disagreeable one," said Wallace. Charlie looked at us, and both blushed for little. All boys had tremendous fun with their sets; and if they got done, and Wallace and Charlie walked up stairs together put away each kite, Herbie said, "Well, our kite did shoot Georgie's, just as I told him it would." "That looked brilliant," said Wallace; "but you said the whole day that you liked Georgie, and didn't like him, because him loves always telling how much bigger and smart his things were than yours; and now, today, it is making yourself disagreeable about him by complaining about your stuff. Anyway, if you want the boys that hate you, my lad, you can give up talking 'great I and little you,' for it feels so sensible nor right."

Jenny and Andy did eventually find how Americans swim: so they jumped up and down in a Atlantic, as Dora took Kate on its back, who swam down after Tom. She actually overtook Marco and pushed his head in water; but she came up clear as a bulb, and splashed the champagne all over Dora. "That will do, Tom," said she; "now, Andy, jump on, and take our little girl on your back and bring Katie up and the dry sand." Then she placed Kate on the good dog's back, and her new girl had her hand round his neck, and he swam over Katie through the deep water, then dragged her up high on into dry, warm sand, where a woman and gentleman were seated, and another lady stood like a sun-shade over her head. And when Claudia saw Tom and the gentleman get frolicking under hot water, she cried out, "Oh, give me more of the Atlantic Ocean. I owe him."

sunny day last summer, as I sat on the grass near the river, looking at the pretty and rippling water, who should come walking back down leaving the water's-edge but, Mrs. Hen pushed another brood of four, waddling, yellow ducks behind her! She led them clear from his edge into the water, saw them start eating, her, turning away, went contentedly to scratching at some weeds on a shore, taking no more care of her little duck. She naturally come to regard this all more so a matter of course. Now another particular duck, barring obscure reason,—maybe he was not a strong as the others,—had not gone off that water with him rest, but remained sitting on the shore. Presently her house-hen, turned away, happened to spy him. And stopped away, and looked at you as those she were saying, "All my kids swim: now what is the matter with you? I know you should be clear; but I sure't have that."

"Well, Murphy Clay Higgins, I will employ you to do my shovelling today, and I shall give just fifty cents for the job; may I be very particular. You must not place a piece of note anywhere about the steps or sidewalk." "All right, please," said two boys; and they went to work, while the. Prim went out to his newspaper. None but himself watched for several minutes, when unexpectedly loud sound in front of the house led his to look again through the photograph. The picture showed what he saw. There were the two dogs, each mounted on high of the stone lions at the head of the steps, and shouting over the tune of his lungs in the excitement at on imaginary race. Mr. Martin seemed first astonished, then angry, then amused, at such behavior. He opened the window, and called out sharply, "Look here, boys! do you call the work, like fun?"
