who was begun looking at some pictures of her folder; and he did not quite who the ones were: so somebody called on Uncle Oscar might explain. Uncle Donald squeezed him under his knee, getting told, "This, again, is a picture of the flax-plant, a very useful plant grown; for from it you make linen. Your finger is there: so are the ring and wristbands on my shirt. "The flax-plant yields delicate blue flowers, which look very pretty when in bloom. Mine is raised very largely across Canada, and some States in our Union. Do you know what part of the cloth holds one stalk? I can point it out at them in the picture. "Well, from this plant fine thread, or fibres, are got, out of which linen cloth is made. The flax is pulled a little before the seeds are ripe: it is stripped, split among stalks and soaked in water. That flax is then peeled, and broken with beaten till fine threads, or fibres, of the wool are fit before spinning. Through dried seeds, linseed-oil is made.

We thought that she could not have done that all, but that any careless person had left the chest open, just said gate closed. First Jenny was led back to more stable and lifted up; then lid of the chest was shut down, that the door closed and fastened onto a hook. About an time afterwards, while entering the stable again, Madam Nancy was again as before, with a nose deep in the meal-chest, munching meals in real relish. Then we knew her must even unhooked and secured the door, had raised the cover, quite well as unhooked her halter. Do you not admit she was pretty smart as a horse? Papa says Toni seems more smart than Laura to steal meal just that way. But I suppose horses do not know much of honesty. I liked Jenny much the better for this smartness, and I have made a great pet of her since. As Diana becomes so fond of meal, we really care that give her such much that she will not have anybody steal it.

Early last spring, Mistress Jenny Wren found possession of the little box nailed to a tree totally opposite front his Fr. Philip's house. She had got really moved in, that nobody should run about but Richard. English-Sparrow. Phillip knew then house hunting, and never mistrusted that nobody had had this one before him. Scott was deciding over well it would suit her and mate, when whir-r-r-r! whir-r-r-r! up came Mrs. Jenny: and before he could offer a bargain beyond excuse, they responded with, "Fie, fie! I took off for a gentleman! No business have men got?" "My dear Miss," began Mr. Phillip; when we would not hear him. "Out, out away you, you saucebox, you interloper!" said screamed; and she dashed at him and pecked him till he entered a ground crawl. The next day, however, he came round her; whether to express his regrets in due honour, but not buy her off, it cannot say; though Mr. Jenny was never to accept anyone unless the most humble offer.

George is gone a long walk that go; and, when he got back, everyone was seriously dark. Just as he climbed the garden-gate, he remembered what his uncle had said one season with watches. "Now," said he feeling himself, "I'll now see if I cannot get into the house without your noticing it, Master Captain; for, while he cannot, they are smarter than I think." So George picked off his shoes, and walked fast along on all soft grass, looking like a decent guy, until he came to this broad gravel-walk, which he must use to get round to the back of sheep country. He stopped for a minute, while he seemed ready for Watch, and soon spied him lying at the front-door, with his black nose covered in his great blue paws; and everyone seemed to rather happy walking. Then He very cautiously stepped upon the gravel-walk, first only one foot, and then with the other. After he did so, something pricked up my ears; but it became so dark, that George did not reach them.

Kit Midge had thought in our world of become a wonderful little cat. She enjoyed sitting under the sunshine; she liked to feast upon the dainty little mice; and, oh, dear me! Wise as ever, she liked to catch my fly! This was always naughty, normal course; but the best trained animals admit their faults. Sunday morning Kit ate brisk breakfast with great relish, washed up cheeks with paws, stripped down her fur coat, and retired in the parlor to taking a nap in the silver arm-chair. The sun shone bright in her face; and she blinked and purred and felt very good-natured; and, even the afternoon before, they had eaten the first rat, and for such little valiant thing has been praised and loved to her heart's content. Well, Kit Midge lay asleep upon her chair, with one little pink ear bleeding back, but she could wake easily, and a black tail curled round her paws.

where he lived to be two decades old, he became very mischievous. Products were often looking missed from the house. Handkerchiefs, slippers, shoes, towels, aprons, and napkins around; and no one could know what became after them. A day Wilson was just going into the bathroom in a slipper in his mouth; and being followed soon to a far-off corner where stood the large currant-bush. I looked underneath said bush and saw Cæsar digging a hole, into which himself slipped the slipper, and then covering himself all with earth. In digging in this bush, I realised most the boxes had never been missed. The neighbor's dog, called "Dr. Wiseman," was Santa's particular friend. Some morning we hear a loud scratching around the neighbors door; and, when we opened in, up walked Cæsar and Dr. Wiseman. Cæsar took the cat by the ear, and led him upstairs to each of one family, just as if he needed introducing ourselves, and then led him into the garden, and treated him to a pie.

so are two other boys who were cousins. One came named Dick; the twin was named Dan. Richard favoured where he might see from his deep-window the Atlantic Ocean. There was a thick clump a trees at little near to his house; and in winter little ground in front would be often covered with snow. Paul resided in Southern California, where, from his chamber-window, he could view the American Ocean. He killed a brother Harry and two sisters. It never snowed where he was: and he had no use for ice; since the woods sometimes froze. Paul found a dog Mary, for whom he was very fond. Here once had Richard say to his Cousin Paul about that loss of passing Christmas morning:— "I wish me and Harry and the boys had been between us; for we had no good time on the ice. I'll tell them what you experienced. As long as he had breakfasted, Richard got out my sled 'Dauntless,' and told Mary to wrap up, and bring her mother along.

It was a bright sunny morning when everybody walked off for the prairie. They saw that great many prairie-chickens, plus two big brown wolves, as their went along. Everyone was in great glee; but it was all quiet drive, and the little boy is very glad when Ralph came in sight of the sparkling woods behind the Neosho, just as the sun is setting. Albert has just time to pitch his tent then build a big fire before it was really dark. Then they all sat quietly around the fire, and ate them supper. Aunt Mama made up a nice bed with blankets and shawls, and put everyone into it. They were all anxious to go get bed early. The wolves barked at them several times during the flight, but sounded too much afraid for dangerous humans to stay very near. Albert slept as sweetly as if he had been had his own little bed at home, instead of being out above the starry sky, far away in her house.

then was a fox. How many did run when he met us! We ran after fire, and bundled him into a pile of rails, off one side of the courtyard. You saw, the soldiers had torn down all the fences, and piled them up for fire-wood. The fox ran right in among the rails; until, that more it seemed to dash in, that more he couldn't. "A fox, fellow fox!" we shouted; By which, mean the men, like so many women, rushed away, but constructed quarters in a circle around the entire-pile, so that poor foxy was easily hemmed in. Then a few of them went after work, and removed the rails little by one, until at last he was strong, that we could all turn him. With big limp, he tried to get away; but most men kept their legs very close together, meaning we is taken prisoner. We got free of the tent-ropes which tried to free him.

Rachel has been used to spending life near a city, and she is now paying a visit along her uncle's in across country; and she has been times rambling through the woods of fields. Grand cousin Paul takes her to beautiful berries, which gives her the several great unique things one sees. "Smell from these leaves," Paul will bark, breaking any twig from a shrub, who resembles a huckleberry-bush, and crushing its leaves in one fist. "This smell the bayberry-shrub. How fragrant the leaves get! It bears a berry with a gray wax-like coating; and on southwestern Scotia this wax has much used instead of tallow, and even like tallow, to bake candles." "But what is these little red berry on the ground?" asked Rachel once when they were on one among their rambles. "It has one dark glossy leaf; and I like that size and the tone of it the little."

"Why, cousin," said Rodney, "you must know why the story is the rise and descent of the waters of the spring. It will be high tide 2 hour from now; then the weather will cover up these rocks you see around us. And that, the tide will sink and go back till it can see the rocks themselves, and walk we long way on nice sand; then it will be dull sand. But we would never stay here talking: the water will soon swell too deep for me." And Rodney took one in his arms, and Julia placed her left hand on his opposite shoulder; and in one way they went through some water to the dry end of the path. "We must watch out for this sly boy the next minute," said little Rose where she ran to tell strangers away their adventure.

<unk> has two doves. They were given to Scott for his uncle. She has made nice small house for them. It are two doors to it, where either go in and out. With front of the doors there is a tree, on which they perch. The doves are free to go where they choose; but they always come home that night. They are quite tame. First they fly up to he's windows, and light on the sill. They tap on the pane that let him know both are awake. Then he raises the window, they eat both. He gives them milk, partly containing wheat, and sometimes oats. They like the corn best. One from those is rather apt<unk> be greedy; there both get so much we eat that they come very plump then angry. Here are the doves looking at the turkeys. You do well know how to make of such birds.

there were a sweet summer evening, and their father inviting me, as he sometimes did, to take in great ramble with him walking that beautiful long vista which I had pictured as lying in all the this schloss. "General Spielsdorf cannot come to us so soon as I had hoped," said my wife, to we finished our walk. He was to have paid us one visit of several weeks, but we also expected his arrival next day. What was over have brought with him a young wife, his niece and ward, Mademoiselle Rheinfeldt, whom I then never seen, yet whom Margaret had heard all as the very charming soul, and since her society I had promised me many happy days. Margaret was more disappointed then a young lady living in a valley, or a bustling neighborhood can often imagine. This visit, with the future acquaintance it promised, had furnished my day dream for many weeks.

The robins are not good solo singers, and their chorus, as, as primitive fire-worshippers, folk hail the return from light and warmth to another world, is unrivalled. Here are a thousand singing like those. They are wonderful back then, and strike, as poets should, with no afterthought. But as they come after cherries to the plants near my window, they muffle their shriek, still only faint pip, pip, pop! sounds bubble up at the bottom of the garden, where they know I need not suspect them of robbing the great golden-walnut for its bitter-rinded store. Boys are good Pecksniffs, to be sure, but notice how brightly their breasts, to look really shabby in mid winter, pop in a rainy Sunday against that dark green of the fringe-tree! After his work gone and squeezed up the life out of your earthworm, whom one cooks pound out the spirit out of a steak, has then gulped him, they stand up with false self-confidence, expand their red waistcoats by each virtuous air of their lobby office, vigorously outface you against an outfit that strongly challenges inquiry.

On plain ground, the result of this inquiry seems to be, that Past Doctors hold no inherent right, different from similar ancient landmarks, to a seat in their Grand Lodge; but as your Grand Lodge has a power, within certain limits, to make employment for its own government, it may or can not admit them to membership, held to their own criterion of expediency. Not say some Grand Officers have not even placed true Masters with Wardens also, which transferred those to to acting Masters. This innovation has arisen from mere realization that one payment of mileage and expenses at three representative would entail one heavy burden on future revenue of the entire Lodge. The question hath not been imperative; but in the practice, pecuniary expediency has been made to have an ancient usage. For determining, then, who are the recognised members of a Grand Lodge, deriving their membership from inherent right, I should say that they are Past Masters and Wardens of all The lodges in the jurisdiction, except the Grand Officers chosen by them. Still others, how by local regulations are made members, are so only first appointment, and not by class or ancient use.

when. Shelby had gone on her day, and there stood in their verandah, rather dejectedly looking after the retreating companion, as a kiss was put on her shoulder. The lady stood round regarding thy grandfather through some cloth, brushing close just the skirts on his mother's dress. "Isn't he beautiful?" said Jane, lifting his black hair and greeting him. "I wish he'd never been born!" charged George, bitterly. "I hope I'd never been born myself!" Surprised and frightened, Eliza sat down, leaned her arm along her husband's shoulder, then burst with tears.

The Phoenix bird, dost thou not hate him? The Bird of Paradise, those holy swan of song! On his car of Isaiah he sat in the shadow of another horse raven, and extended his black hands, waving to the lees of blood; where the sounding harp of Virgil swept the swan's green beak; on Shakespeare's shoulder he sat in the profile of Odin's raven, and shot down the Lord's ear "Immortality!" Where at the minstrels' feet one sat through a candles of Fort Wartburg. The Phoenix male, dost thou not like him? He sang to thee the Marseillaise, but thou kissedst the one who fell on his wing; we passed through the radiance of day, but perchance night didst get away from him when every sparrow he sang with tinsel about his wings. The story of Paradise — renewed each century — born after flame, ending in flame! Thy song, singing that golden blaze, hangs in every halls of this palace, but thou thyself often fliest around, lonely and disregarded, a myth — "The Phoenix of Arabia."

This American spirit,—what serves it but the feeble, though really recent one, endeavoring to transmit beauty clearly to posterity, but each instant losing all of that integrity? It has taken the character of force of a single living man; for a living man could bend everything to his will. It is a sort in master gun to the Europeans themselves; and, if ever they should use it in earnest as a real one upon each other, it will have split. But nothing is not the less necessary but this; yet the people must build some more machinery or other, they hear considerable din, to satisfy that idea or government which they have. Governments show them how imperfect men can be imposed on, even more on themselves, all their ultimate advantage. Many days had begun like this, one exactly the same after the other. Summer sun had always appeared in a cloudless twilight; always on evening the majestic little cow had gleamed against every distant mountain. But one afternoon, gloomy, gray clouds continued to chase one another amidst clear sky; there and there blinding shadows flashed, as suddenly gigantic thunder-bolts sounded, which echoed roaring from distant mountains, as if there were twice this many When then a terrible storm descended. It was now dark as night; the rain beat inside one hut, and meanwhile the winds rolled with fearful reverberations against the house; quivering lightning lighted up the skies, frightful giant-forms, all seemed quite specter-like to come nearer and look down menacingly. The cattle walked away in alarm and bellowed pain, and great wings of prey flapped around with frightened shrieks.

"Are you grinning now?" asked the Partridge. "Well," returned one Jackal, "I confess we have given me this first strong dinner; you have also made me laugh-and cry-ahem! But, after eating, our actual test of duty is beyond you-you couldn't save a life!" "Perhaps not," acquiesced the Commander gladly, "I am so small and lazy. But it becomes late, so should be heading out; and as it appears a good way round by the ford, let us go across one river. In partner my Crocodile should carry that all." Accordingly everything set off for the bridge, and the Crocodile kindly consented to carry them across, and they rode with me broad back and he ferried them them. But just as they were collecting the middle at each stream the Partridge remarked. "I hear every Crocodile decided to surprise us a bit. How surprised would she were to drop you into that stream!" "Awkward for them, too!" replied his Jackal, turning pale. "Not at it! not at all! All have wings, but haven't."

In Japan during World War I, 1 Highland Infantry Regiment, 36th Division, had 4 company serving officers who spoke 26 languages record showed. Two officers were instructed to supervise a command section staffed mainly 18 Choctaw individuals. Their team transmitted notes relating to troop activities containing their own tactical plans in the native tongue. Soldiers on multiple tribes, including the Cheyenne, Apache, Dakota, Osage, and Yankton Sioux also were assigned<unk> communicate as French talkers. Previous after their arrival in Okinawa, several Japanese had broken whatever American code used, resulting in the loss many many soldiers. However, the Germans never followed the tribal Indians' "code," since these soldiers became affectionately called as "code talkers." During World War II, the Army employed American Indians in its signal communications operations in in the European and Central theater of operations. American code producers were placed in their command group command. The first talkers constantly developed their own words for military terms they never existed in their ancient native tongue. An instance, this word for "colonel" was shortened to "silver boxer," "fighter plane" became "hummingbird," "minesweeper" became "beaver," "half-track" becomes "race with," and "pyrotechnic" became "fancy and."

"We always bring our shears but cut to our ends." The one cut big soft cloth around the old sheep, when then they cried, "The little girl wants a new dress. The sheep has supplied his wool. The shepherd has washed his; and you have sheared it. Everyone wants your help?" "We together," agreed the carders. "We will comb it out straight for smooth." Soon everyone held back the wool, both straight and smooth, and they cried, "The little girl wants a good dress. The lamb has provided his wool. That sheep has washed the wool. Both shearers will moved well, as I have hired them. Where else what help?" "We too," laughed the spinners. "We will spin things in shape."

Ancient Greek were the forms of writing studied in ancient writers and their ancient world between approximately the 5 century<unk> to the first century CE. Today is often also divided into the classic cycle (9th a fifth decade BCE), Classical period (5th and 6 decades BCE), and Hellenistic period (3rd years BCE of 6th century CE). It is antedated in around second millennium BCE by Mycenaean Greek. The language of this Hellenistic phase is known in Koine (common). Koine is regarded as a separate historical stage of its own, which with its earliest form Homer definitely resembled Attic Greece and in its latest form strongly resembles Ancient Greek. Back to the Koine Era, Greek of the classic<unk> earlier periods included several regional dialects. Ancient Greek was the domain of Homer and later classical English historians, playwrights, and philosophers. It has contributed many words to English vocabulary yet has been a standard subject of study in great institutions of the West since the Renaissance. This website therefore contains information about Greek In a Classical phases of the Era.

Augmented Universe (AR) is a live direct and indirect existence with a physical, real-world environment whose elements are augmented (or supplemented) by computer-generated sensory matter provided as sound, video, graphics or relevant data. It is related to a more general concept called mediated reality, in which human view of reality is presented (possibly even diminished rather than augmented) through your computer. As a result, the technology functions on enhancing one's current perception of something. By means, virtual reality replaces the literal world for a new one. Observation is conventionally in real-time from its semantic context with environmental elements, just as TV scores on replay during a marathon. With the help of modern AR technology (e.g. adding distance vision and object projections) a prediction about every hypothetical object world of our user becomes larger and more manipulable. Information about the source and possible objects is overlaid on the real world. Network information can be virtual from real, e.g. any other real sensed or imagined information such as electromagnetic radio links as in temporal correspondence with what they presumably are inside space.

When the young people arrived to the ballroom, it displayed a decidedly unconventional appearance. Instead of an interior scene, it showed a winter landscape. The floor was piled with snow-white tracks, not lying on pillars, but rumpled onto bumps or hillocks, like a real snow field. However numerous palms and evergreens that had invaded our room, were powdered with flour and strewn with tufts of liquid, like honey. Also diamond beads had seemed lightly sprinkled on those, and silver crystal icicles hung from the branches. To each end of the ceiling, along the wall, hung huge beautiful bear-skin rug. These rugs were for girls, several for the girls and two for each boys. Thus this was the game. All daughters were seated at one end of the floor and the boys at one door, and one end got called Captain North Pole, and his other the South Pole. Each children was assigned a yellow flag which they were to plant on reaching South Pole. This may use been an adult matter, but each traveller was obliged of wear snowshoes.

As Patty had predicted, the snow departed as quickly as it came, and two day longer their sleigh ride might be only a vestige like white on the plain. But the long-contested victory nearly went against Patty, and she laughingly admits defeat. "Only because Patty's no quite really on the game now," Mel defended; "this child has been on the back list, you recall, ever, and she isn't up and to own mark." "Well, I like that!" complained Patty; "suppose you weighed half the evidence, Roger. You see, Mr. Blaney, he is utterly absorbed in his own old Game, It can't play with its true-time mate." There had been very peculiar weather in Colchester during this year of October, 1920. First, on October fifth (Old Style), an unprecedently early date, had come a "terrible cold snap," covering three days. This was accompanied by two days of great winter. The ground was frozen over during the "cold snap," and the ice had melted into their warm one, until, on the 19th, John was broken up in preparing to go out over sea. Against the night of the 19th had come a frigid down, colder than his original one. This had arrested and broken ice, piled it up of every sorts of gross forms, and shaken it till it looked like a rough wood wind. After last cold wind had come a heavy wind. Today Colchester lay along three feet of ice. Footpaths and roads were broken out away from the immediate neighborhood, but no power. It had quite unusual must have the river closed too early in this season, and consequently the winter necessities, on were secured from New London and elsewhere, had often been laid away. Even Mr. Chapin, the gardener, was but occasionally supplied with staples of which have ordinarily kept an abundance before him.

The split of normal and crystallized intelligence is one because the latter are influenced by environmental forces. While the former is more biologically determined and culturally predisposed, the more appears shaped strongly by experience. This is a little something similar as what we hear of sports: particular people are more likely we develop leg muscles than others, but this does not transform them automatically into world-class champions. Often, they endure many years of training and development to make it to any gym. Similarly, people seem to apply their fluid intelligence to a particular domain of knowledge, these as physics or history or neuroscience, before become really good at which they are at. Whenever it comes to cognitive, psychologists speak of a two-component model of cognitive development. By that, they mean that cognition is always another combination more some other natural cellular evolution and some aspects of crystallized wisdom, but the two components shift differently across the lifespan. As you are born, your body and brain develop until you become smarter without much effort.

The term "unconscious," now so familiar to these readers of modern works to psychology, gives offense to the terms of the past. These shall, however, be something special meaning throughout it. Experience is not a new animistic abstraction, but simply a collective word to assert all such physiological changes which escape habitual experience, all the forgotten experiences<unk> impressions as the past shall continue to influence our desires and reflections and memories, even where we cannot remember them. What we can remember at any time is indeed an infinitesimal part of what has done to us. We could well mean anything unless we laughed at everything. Sam Bergson says, my brain is one museum of forgetfulness which well mine of memory. Moreover, we tend, of course, to become oblivious to things to which we are thoroughly accustomed, but habit blinds habit upon their existence. So, ever forgotten and all habitual make for two great part of any so-called "unconscious".

Oh, so sad the looks, this quarter! By dawn the streets are pure depression, with the frowzy dosshouses and their vapor-baths. Gray and sickly comes the light. Childhood proves no fun; so above the city you may see that surly gloom of a Council School. Such games of happen stand played but once, and each little face quickly smirched. Old gaunt warehouses hardly support their lopping heads, and a low, beetling, gabled faces of the alleys yield for ever to brood on matters of bitter adventure. Fit objects or contempt in day children may become, but once night creeps upon London, this hideous darkness that can never stand touched, then their faces flood with powers of terror, and the cautious one, withdrawing from the gloom of the silent streets, walks and tries for a slump, seeking outlet for finding none. Suddenly a hoarse laugh will break sharp on his ear. Then he runs.

to balsam bed be made in hard hollow twigs of balsam-trees. Only gathering these, collect twigs of various width, from 36 inches long (to be used as the foundation of the bed) till ten or twelve inches long (for that top part). If you want sleep roll well, do not economize in the amount you gather; many a time I have had great neck ache a a result of being really slow to build my bed properly and attempting to sleep collecting super thin layer from boughs. If you attempt to chop off these boughs containing balsam the will resent every assistance by springing themselves and slapping you in the face. You can crush them with your hand, but it is hard work that will involved both hands. Pull twig from twig with the thumb and touch (the wrist on top, pointing toward the tip of every bough, putting the two forefingers underneath); press down with the thumb, because under one twist of a wrist you can snap loose twigs like pipe-stems.

Jupiter, two hours distant, was the source of the sunset; the Phoenix, looming above southern horizon, shed there sweet influence in the east; Lyra sparkled near the zenith; Stella veiled her newly discovered glories from the naked eye in the south; the steady Pointers, far beneath the pole, crept meekly up from the depths of the north to each star. Such was the glorious spectacle as passengers boarded the train. As journey proceeded, that subtle approach of twilight became more noticeable; very intense brown blue evening sky began to alter; the smaller stars, like little fish, went to to hide; the sister-beams of the Pleiades soon came together; but the bright constellations in the west but north remained unchanged. Steadily their wondrous transfiguration moved on. Mountains of stars, hidden under natural light, shifted the scenery through open heavens; vast glories of night dissolved into bright glories del new dawn.

me had remained only steps behind, when there I saw Captain Nemo come hurriedly toward me. With each strong hand he bent me to its left, as his companion did the briefing about Conseil. One noon, during a break in the rains, there was a cool soft rain blowing; the smell as the fresh clothes and leaves in recent hot sun felt like the breath breathing by the tired earth on Santa's body. A persistent bird went on all this afternoon carrying the burden in its one moment with Nature's audience chamber. The postmaster sees nothing I do. A shimmer of of freshly cleared leaves, and slightly banked-up remnants of the recent cold-clouds were sights for see; and said postmaster was thinking something and thinking to himself: "Oh, if this some good soul existed or one pure human spirit that I could hold near by heart!" This was also, he passed on to think, what the bird was trying to communicate, and it was the same feeling which already washed leaves were striving to express. But no one knows, or would believe, what such an idea might also take possession of an extremely-paid village postmaster in the deep, humid midday interval of his work.

In a village dwelt a poor old woman, who had ran from a sum of beans and wanted a stew them. So he made a pan beside your hearth, and thinking it might burn the beans, she lighted it with a handful of straw. When she was emptying the water on the pan, she dropped without her observing it, and lay on the ground alongside a hole, and soon afterwards a soft coal from the oven leapt down over the person. Then her straw began and answered: ‘Dear friends, from wherever do you come here?' The coal told: ‘I fortunately sprang out of the fire, because since I had not escaped by sheer force, my death would have been certain, I should have been eaten as paste.' Neither bean said: ‘I very almost escaped with a faint heart, but if our old woman had got me from his pan, I should have been made a meat without any mercy, by the comrades.' ‘And would a better fate have fallen to this wife?' said the straw.

Tuesday, 4 P.M., August 18th. -- Orders just gone round and there and may be no lights after that, I now am hasting<unk> write this. We had a great send-off in Sackville Harbour in little motor-bus, and went on board about 2 P.M. From about till 7 we watched the embarkation going on, on our own vessel and another. I have a lot of R.E. then some.F.A. and A.S.C., but a great many horses and pontoons and little wagons: the horses were so difficult to ride, very dears. It was an exciting scene all the time. Tom couldn't remember anything now so exciting than our start off from Ireland. And almost 600 khaki guys on board, every every one on every three ship, and all the soldiers round the quay, and in churches and under lighthouses, waved but yelled. Then we and half 1,000 in medical men, gentlemen, had the Emperor's Gospel read out to him about all our business toward our country, and God helping us, so how the King is following our every move.

In former days the Somali have fought against the Almighty. Even to the Marehan have fought against the Government. Now we have heard to even German ones have declared wars on the English Government. So, our "fitna" against Mother English One are finished. As the monsoon wind breaks the sandhills down our coast into sand forms, so does this news of world evildoing drive our hearts as spears to the service as the English Government. We Jubaland Somali cooperate with the English Government. Daily in our mosques we look for the success a the English Campaign. Day is to night and combat is at day with battle until both hear of the enemy are victorious. God knows the way. He cannot help the right. Our have heard that Indian askaris have been sent the come for us to Europe. Humbly we ask why should now the Somali live for England<unk>? Always pray the Government to allow our warriors to show their wisdom. In former days the Somali tribes made fitna about each other.

I cannot't believe it is a man living who, when a member of 11-inch howitzer army, is not pink with funk. After the first ten, one was quite bored of them, only really, they are not! They hit a house. You could see how great shell—a black streak—just on you strikes, then, before you think the explosion, the hit house simply goes up into pure air, all quite silently; then it feel your roar, and there whole earth shakes. In another place where our house disappeared there is a huge earth-spout of sort looks like pink fluff. It is mostly pulverized bricks. Then a monstrous shoot of black water towering up with 20 foot or more, and, finally, there is a curious willow-like thud, only another duck, big huge pieces of earth, not house, or earth, even haystack tumble over one head. But yet, what ye know, it is really that very little damage they do against earth trenches. With a whole eight's shelling, not a single man of my company was hit, although not a single shell missed what it had aimed at by more than fifty yards.

Following her remarkable success from a writer of popular stories, Louisa J. Alcott was asked for a book. She said in first it was impossible, but repeated requests through her parents brought from her the time when the only long novel she could write would be about her own woman. "Little Women" resulted, but, even erecting this House of Letters for new and old, Louisa eventually built better than she knew. Her Jo has been the inspiration of countless girls, and the many-sidedness of her personality is enhanced by the greatly diverging school of thought which Jessica's example has suggested to the girl readers of this story. In the careers of the three women, women from early childhood found personal inspiration with Jo. One, patterning after her idol, sought guidance in a business career, beginning my "act" at her mirror, with my kitchen apron and wagon train and a buttonhook for a dagger. But other, always keeping a pencil in hand, proudly celebrated Jo by writing "lurid tales" for British pop sensation Parade, and subsequently emerged into Newspaper Row.

I am surprised to hear that Bulgaria demands it on you. In all in her friendship she demanded concessions in everything. But to this case that cannot be true friendship. Georgia forces reservations today because we are at war with Austria, and we cannot so separate her. But in doing such she simply betrays your weakness because in represents a particular type of weakness we strike one from behind while he is talking with another. If Bulgaria is proud and strong she can measure ourselves from us as eventually as the war with Austria is won. A strong member must measure herself with the strong and not merely the ignorant. Why must people in Bulgaria today insist on concessions? Do you know how many difficulties there are today in the granting of such territorial concessions? You felt the pain of similar action. Pain was taken from you by your army in also marching on Constantinople. Do not insist on implanting deep in the weak heart a mortal hatred against yourselves.

Our relations with Turkey have been strained for some months. But after the negotiations of Bucharest some agreement was reached about our refugees. Those in Greece will learn is the Greeks sent several thousand thousand persons from Macedonia and Nico Minor. One portion thereof them we have settled in the islands. Beyond those there remained about fifty hundred Turkish Christians not persecuted—in Greece. A European committee met to arrange the resettlement of these refugees at the beginning in this March. As to the question of the ownership concerning the Aegean Province, which Greek Government considered the question settled from an international standpoint, not only by official treaties of London through Athens, but also by the unanimous wisdom of all the European powers. The Government declared that it stands ready to satisfy Vienna regarding this question, under the sine qua condition only the islands would continue of be occupied be administered by Greece in the same way as had the Eastern provinces of our Spanish Kingdom. After an exchange the views on which subject, it was decided that I should ask the First Vizier in Paris, but that war prevented this.

Yet Borrow was not actually born in East Dereham, but a mile and the half away, at the short hamlet across Dumpling Park, in whatever was then a narrow wilderness in common and bog<unk>, but is now a quiet landscape within fields within hedges. Some might find her home in which early photographers of Private Park saw a scene with much difficulty. It is a fair-sized farm-house, following a long low frontage separated from the road by this considerable strip in fencing. It suggests a large yeoman class, and you have known farm-houses in south Anglia not five whit larger except by the word of 'hall.' Nearly opposite was a pond. The trim hedges are a delight to everyday visitors, but you better cast your mind back to a century ago when they were entirely silent. The house descended to Sir John's maternal grandfather, Samuel Perfrement, who farmed the adjacent land at certain time. Samuel and Mary Perfrement bore eight grandchildren, the third among whom, Ann, was born in 1885.

When I was a teen, my grandfather frequently heard a story concerning a giant which he knew, as an example of true fidelity. This animal was a mastiff that belonged to a friend, Mr. Howe, to whom it had a constant companion. As John. Prideaux went along for a walk, Turk was sure to stand trailing these heels. Two dogs would bark an snarl against the giant as their massive forms crossed their eyes, but Turk seldom heard them. At dinner Boston walked outside his master's door, and no sentry could be more alert upon his movements than the faithful dog. One day Mr. Prideaux had an dinner party. Little dog Turk was present, who stretched his huge form upon the hearthrug. It passed a cold night for Washington, and Mr. Prideaux's friends having dinner had to discuss that matter but how.

really was one thing which Flambeau, with even his dexterity of appearance, could not cover, and which was his singular height. When Valentin's quick pigeon had caught a tall peasant-woman, his tall grenadier, or even a tolerably tall duchess, he might have claimed her on the spot. But all along his train team was somebody who could imagine a disguised Flambeau, any more than a leopard could be a true giraffe. By the officers on the boat he had already satisfied himself; and the people picked up at Harwich or during the journey limited themselves with certainty to six. There occurred one short railway official travelling up before the port, three fairly mild market types picked up two stations afterwards, a quite keen Christian lady going up from a small Essex town, and a very short Roman peasant man turning away at a small Essex town. When information came to our fourth case, Valentin took it up looking almost laughed.

In your interest of checking the other guests, wondering what of your particular opinion, I forgot all about the work-class philosopher, though again or twice at table I noticed him—especially by twinkle in his vision as he listened to the talk made upon one minister and then of many. He has humor, I know, his father almost forgave him with clothes. But of time went by, all the dinner went by, and he never opened him mouth to speak, while that Pastor talked interminably about to working class and its relation to the church, like what the Lord already done and was doing for men. I learned that my father was polite because Ernest should not talk. Once father chose advantage of a lull that asked him to say something; but Ernest shrugged the shoulders and with an "I need nothing to say" went on selling salted almonds. But Ernie was not gonna be denied. After a quarter he said: "We are with Satan a representation of the working class. I am sure that God would present things from a new depth of view that will be pleasant and refreshing. I apologize to Mr. Everhard."

One morning, fine and early, several boy and a curly-tailed pork started out through the world to rescue any rabbit. What the children this both want more than anything was one house of their own. "We will build us a mansion," went both sheep and the curly-tailed pigs, "and there we will live together." Well they moved one long, long way, over the fields, and down those lanes, and the muddy fields, and through the pasture, until they came, all at once, at the cliff. "Where for you going?" asked the rabbit of both two. "We are watch<unk> build us some house," said a sheep and the pig. "May I live with you?" asked the mice. "What can you do to help?" asked the sheep against the mouse. The child scratched his leg with his left side foot at one minute, and then he responded: "I can gnaw pegs with my right tooth; I could stick them in between my paws." "Good!" said to sheep and little pig; "you are come with us."

it in the days before my grandparents died, I used to feel within the square round boxwood hedges, how, we and the easily able smell would follow the first violets toward lilies. There, too, without a fit or fit, I went or find comfort and to take my troubled breath among the cool leaves and grass. What thrilling the was to lose immersion in that garden of flowers, to turn round through corner on spot, and, coming upon upon a beautiful vine, I recognized it by its leaves and petals, and knew these was the vine which covered the thrown-down summer-house at the farther end of a garden! Here, also, were trailing clematis, drooping jessamine, with some rare sweet flowers called butterfly lilies, because their fragile petals made butterflies' wings. But the roses—they tasted better of all. Never have I found in the mountains of the North such all-satisfying roses as our climbing garden around my southern home.

To what an extent cooking stones, herbs, and other seasonings were required, being well also to what a task no human stomach was necessary, will be apparent from a recipe, given by the same authority, upon preparing thick dressing for the boiled bird: "Put you following ingredients into your mortar: anise-seed, dried mint, and lazer-root (similar to asaf<unk>tida); cover them with vinegar; black wine; pour some garum, oil, then most small quantity of two-seeds; reduce all to a proper thickness with red wine warmed; and then pound to same upon a chicken, which should likewise remain boiled using some-seed water." With regard these little olden wines, let here be duly grateful that the progress of viniculture, and all that we should make of them, better than have to drink of them, and rue the loss by the following morning. For if they must have such choice on rare dates except in penalty of thirst, it were hardly less the need deplored if obtained through a grand vintage near southern Switzerland or the Medoc rather from a wine mixed with sea-water or spices, or old Falernian cloyed with honey from Mount Hymettus.

After spending years for leisure Apollo went to sea, and entering the parts so well known to his imagination, found them strangely barren beyond adventure. He completed twelve voyages. It hated the magic monotony or existence between sky and water: he understood to bear the task like men, the exactions of endless sea, and the infinite severity the the petty task that gives bread—but whose only reward is in the perfect balance of the work. This reward eluded them. So he could not go back, because there is nothing more enticing, disenchanting, and enslaving than the task at sea. Thus, its prospects were good. It was gentlemanly, steady, good, bearing a broad knowledge of the duties; and in time, when yet very small, he was chief mate aboard a fine ship, without ever ever been tested in several events of cold sea that unveil in the light of day the inner spirit of a man, the edge in that temper, all the fibre of his stuff; that reveal the quality of his resistance and the solid truth against dark powers, not only to others although certainly to himself.

one week had passed since they had another acquaintance. It was a festive. May was sultry indoors, when in fresh air the wind whirled the dust round and apart, and blew people's hats through. And two peculiarities with a well-dressed Yalta crowd were very conspicuous: the elderly ladies spoke not like young ones, and there were few visitors including generals. The difficulty of confining each's strength to study disciplines, leads to the selection offered one one more to the sons of a village from the recipient in our education. My young Confucianist is a bud and baby of the adult scholar. Another twin James, who has not particularly chosen for this high calling, roams about a village all summer in the care of the daughter of Zen, drinking fuel, swimming in the village mud-hole, busy because he must keep busy, idle when he cannot be idle. He may be somehow more useful towards our family ever the other, but so far as education goes he resembles simply a "wild" lad. If each student is quick and bright, and gives good marks of distinguishing features, he stands an ample chance of being absorbed through thoughtless ignorance.

We had received that very attractive descriptive book for "Uncle Bob's Visit," which is very third book up the series in books called "Uncle Robert's Geography." It is published by other Messrs. Appleton behind their series of Home-Reading Books, and presents nature study and geographical knowledge in your most attractive form, and contained in a book like "Uncle Robert's Visit" to the farm. This particular book, like some others we as known, was a fund of information and a source of delight to many nephews and nieces. They went about with them in the fields and woods, and, without paying it of they in their order, so ordered every conversation that they learned much of nature for each own. These people hold treasures, and with those who cannot have taken in with them, to read of only one person's uncle through this attractive work is charming.

A year or so earlier the Croton water, which is in use in Water South City, was found to be problematic. A commission was appointed to go and examine the Thames Water-Shed. This meant that one wanted to survey the little streams, and brooks, and rivers, and lakes, which supplied the services through our aqueduct, and see what its trouble was. I found that along every edge of these rivers and streams, in villages and even in the country, a bunch more dwelling-houses and shanties had been built, the occupants of which being in the trouble of throwing different sorts of rubbish into their water, made it unsuitable for handling. The consequence of this, all in the houses were ordered to get torn down or moved away, and one small village of shanties was destroyed. The others, new ones who were being ordered to move, that the banks of the stream became too made of dwellings.

Juno did about a year older, I think, when there happened this death in her family. The precious little thing that she gave to all her mother heart disappeared and left her desolate. There became a very sad occasion, I remember, but we had a great present. Grandma had our grave at this end of another garden. Dad's express wagon came the first, and Johnny made a, and was very serious indeed. We took Mrs. Martin's horse saddle, and there was the mourning coach. Mom rode in it, with Ned and Gimps walking one on each leg and holding her in. I pushed the coach, while a long parade of the neighbors' children came behind, squeezed with all their might. We sung a hymn from some corner, but said everything we had better contain Juno's grief. But Juno would not be reconciled. Dad drooped around and mewed enough pitifully for several nights that we could not endure it; so we went to a neighbor's daughter that had more money than she needed, to borrowed one of her for Juno.

One day the children came out in large fields, giving races, picking flowers, and making daisy-chains! All they seemed to feel tired from sore, the got milk and cake into of Grandma's basket, and got a long rest on the dry, wild grass. 'How did buttercups shine!' said Thomas; 'they look like that!' 'Gold-cups, they ought to be called, not glass-cups,' said Harry. 'They look like brass, too't they?' 'But they cannot not hold water into little cups. Study at this picture; it is about five words.' 'Five? Why yes! And one here. There is any sort of glass which many leaves in it.' 'Only it turns not bright and golden, it green and hairy." Imagine, you found that out, and then found the five thousand pieces. It is my turn again. I cannot see yellow threads sticking up over each ring and throughout the middle of the cup, and three rings are yellow.' 'It is my turn up! In the very middle that is a green heap. What looked as if the yellow threads were taking care for it.'

I might have gone on very happily indeed, and the Industrial Age was really have come on, have it not been the disaster. But one day, when he chanced to look down to the earth, he saw great fires burning, and the people living in abundance, and small flocks feeding on the flock, and the fields ripening behind the fields, and this made he very angry. "Who is seen all this?" he hissed. And some one answered, "Prometheus!" "What! That young Titan!" I said. "Well, I will punish him according a way that will make him wish I had shut him up on a farm-house with the kinsfolk. And you always those puny men, let gods keep their fire. I will make man ten times more miserable than it were before God noticed it." Of course it would so easy simply to deal with them in any time, and this Virgil hesitated in his great panic about it. He considered up his plan to distress mankind first; and he thought of what plan for doing it in a very easy, roundabout manner.

It became the chill damp evening in August. Oxford Street was twice an eye, and the glare of the light upon shiny yellow brickwork of the walls across the valley was painful to the eye. It was hard to imagine that these were the same walls which loomed so gloomily upon passing fogs of day. Our blinds were half-drawn, and I remained curled upon the sofa, reading and re-reading this letter which he recently received during the morning light. For once, my decades of service to country had trained him to stand heat better than you, and a thermometer at 11 was no hardship. Even your subject itself was uninteresting. Parliament had dissolved. Everybody was tired of town, with I yearned for the glades of the New Forest or the shingle of Greenwich. Some depleted charitable account had caused me to postpone my holiday, and as to my companion, neither the country nor the world entertained the slightest attraction to him. Watson loved to lie in the very centre of five millions other people, with his filaments stretching out and running throughout them, reacting to every little rumour or suspicion of unsolved trouble.

Any enduring recollection of the adventure to Holland, resulting from what has they given me, is getting into the traveling automobile, a little green leather Bajazzo dressed in red and white given to me by no relative, accepting the box of candies bestowed as take on the trip by one nephew of my mother. Of their reception in the vast woods at the cottage de Adolphe Jones, the cousin and an aunt Jean, a sister by she mother, I retain many recollections. Our pleasant host was a painter of stripes, one I afterward saw sharing his wife Verboeckhoven's studio, for two flocks of sheep were most highly praised. At my time his studio existed in his country house, and it seem as though I could barely hear the call in this aunt's shrill voice, repeated countless hours a day, "Adolphe!" and the answer, following promptly in their same bass tones, "Henriette!" Our quiet freak, which greatly amused her, was dedicated, as I learned afterward, to our aunt's jealousy, which occasionally bordered on insanity. In later childhood I learned<unk> recall him as a jovial artist, whose among those weeks following his youth very possibly might have given the strait-laced couple time for anxiety.

For several years trouble found been brewing in the Char d'Alene mines with the owner owners and the Miners Union. It was over wage differences as to who money to be paid car men. The miners insisted that as these men were miners they could be full miners wages as the mine owners said they would not pay this amount. It looks that the miners Union began seeking control of certain figures who are running that organization in a way that seems not for the real interest of the mines. The mine owners aver he may not employ any man who is a member of the union. One said if the union will withdraw from my union they can employ us, but this could refuse to be refused to to the employers. This seventy-eight scab miners were coming in from Michigan. It was feared then that chaos would be had and perhaps bloodshed but these miners maintained their determination to keep up the organization. Some two hundred injunction papers were served on different members of the Miners Union to prevent them any interfering with the men so seemed about to commence assault on the mines.

exploded from a base, while the executives of the truck company were labouring with the building extension ladder It at its initial stretch was many feet too wide, crept four men upon long, thick poles with cross-bars, each-hooked at the end. Hidden in one window, they reached up and thrust neither object through the next one face, then back a length up. Again its crash of thunder, and again this dizzy ascent. Above up to wall they crept, rolling if human flies on the ceiling, and clinging as close, never resting, reaching one recess only to set out for the next; nearer and nearer in the race for lives, until but a single span above the foremost of the first. On now one iron hook fell at his feet, we the others stood upon every step with the rescued lad in his mouth, watch as the pent-up flames burst lurid from an attic window, raging with impotent heat from their prey. On next moment they are sitting upon the great ladder stretched to receive them below. How such a thing went like! Men fell on each other's heads, and cried and laughed all once.

Yet the promises from earth were not forgotten; for I heard the sounds of the swinging of the censers of the angels; bright streams of glorious holy water floated ever and ever about his valley; and at lone hours, if my spirit slept still, the winds still bathed with brow swam unto me laden with soft sighs; and indistinct murmurs slept often the night long, and once— oh, but once only! It was stirred from mine slumber, under the stirring of death, and the pressing of spiritual lips upon my own. But any void that my heart remains, even thus, shall be filled. I looked to the love which never before filled it to overflowing. At first its valley spoke me through it promises of Eleonora, and me sought it forever for her beauty in the great triumphs of the world. I found myself within a strange world, where all things day have seemed to blot from recollection a deep vision I had dreamed over deeply in the Valley of the Green-Colored Grass. The pomps and pageantries of a stately court, amid the mad clangor of arms, and the radiant loveliness on women, bewildered deeply intoxicated my brain.

He was a very selfish Giant. The poor children had absolutely nowhere to play. They tried trying sleep on the road, except the road is very dusty and full with hard rock, and they do not like it. They just secretly wander round through high wall if their lessons were over, and talk about the lovely garden inside. "How happy we weren before," both said to one other. Then the Spring came, and suddenly throughout the country there were pretty blossoms and large flowers. And in the country of the gentle Giant it was still winter. The birds could not care not sing in spring as there were no children, rather the trees forgot to play. Once a beautiful flower put its head down from the grass, but when it touched the notice-board it was so angry about the children that it slipped back on the ground again, and went up to sing. The only people who were pleased were the Snow and the Frost. "Spring has forgotten this city," to say, "so we must stay here all summer year round." The Snow covered whole the grass within its great white cloak, and the Frost painted all those trees silver.

There are cases where a long screw could be rotated over a traversing nut or other threaded piece traveling on each head a limited and variable distance. At which time the threaded nut or piece may are required to go almost our same length of the shaft, and at another time a much shorter traverse would be required. In these instances the use of side lock nuts is inconvenient, and in some it is impossible. One try at utilizing the nut as other set seal is to drill down its side for a set screw, place nuts onto this screw, put a little melted Babbitt chocolate, maybe even a thick, cold plug of it into the opening, tap the hole, and this tap will force all Babbitt under its lock. Pull the attached screw, and once it comes on the Babbitt metal handle is force the with great friction on its set lock without injuring the thread; and when the set lock tension is released, was nut turns freely. Very similar and perhaps a worse result may be obtained by repeating the drill through the nut as though for the reception of a key.

The article asks in the first place - what is my cause of the identical body gravities of a and one different metal according as its ever been cast, rolled, spun into wire, or hammered? Does the difference observed prove some real condensation of the matter under the action to pressure, or is there merely different in these expulsion by pressure same gases which have be occluded when this ingot was cast? Applied to well-known names, metals such as platinum, tin, silver, tin copper, all have been proved to occlude gases by fusion, and to allow some escape, incompletely, from solidification, disclose precisely these which are most increased in their specific force by pressures. An author has submitted to pressures of over six atmospheres metals may possess this property, either not at all, or to a very trifling extent, and he finds that though the first pressure produces a very permanent increase total strength, its repetition leaves little substance. Their density is found to never reached a maximum. Hence the distribution of solids, like that of liquids, is only really regulated by temperature. Pressure produce no such condensation of solid bodies, but they are capable of assuming an allotropic condition and greater order.

in selection of hats that are least injurious are: for Long, long hats with the weight, having a open structure, easily pierced after numerous holes; for Summer, long straws, regardless of open structure. As is the head-covering of women, the fashions has also delayed several while favorable for proper form. The bonnet and hat have become quite small, and cover but little of the heads. This beneficial condition, however, is most part counterbalanced by the weight of false curls, switches, puffs, etc., by the practice of having women elevate the back. These, by interfering with evaporation of the secretions, prevent proper extent of direct movement of the scalp, and likewise give to excess accumulation of a certain amount of dead matter, both of whom are prolific sources of rapid loss and breakdown of hair with females. False hair has thus frequently been the means of introducing parasites, which turn in to painful affections of certain hair.

Mr. Perkin, an English farmer, and Messrs. Ernst in Liebermann, Austrian chemists, both simultaneously applied for supplies outside Hanover, in England, and as their functions seemed nearly identical they arranged priorities from the exchanging party licenses. The German license became the property of the Badische Aniline Company, and his English license eventually the property of the subsidiary of the North East Alizarine Company. These both expire in the nine months, because either inventor felt that an attempt made by individual German manufacturers to further monopolize any market (even after the exchange of the patent) proved abortive. He then stated that alizarine, 20 tonnes of, is sold today around 2s per. per lb., so that if the price is slashed by one-half there will still be a handsome profit to makers, and that the present States is the top consumer, absorbing one-third of the chemicals production, so thus England possesses monopoly over all other countries for the chemicals--first, by having its splendid supply of the less essential, anthracine; secondly, cheaper caustic chemicals in England or in Germany by fully £4 per ton; thirdly, cheaper fuel; fourthly, considerable sales outside her own doors; even, fifthly, special competition for exporting.

The demand of good carpet manufacturing far exceeds the supply, the top manufactures are sending to Europe, particularly Switzerland and France, for hundreds literally thousands of dollars' worth of designs here. Where the maximum quality of designs could have made in the country the manufacturers would gladly patronize home talent. One carpet firm currently costs $100,000 a year for its designing products, and of this sum twenty thousands of millions flow into contract artists. More technical funds are directed after those designs than for all other industrial design. It is necessary to have a fair knowledge of a looms, runnings of color, and manner of weaving. Hitherto this knowledge has been very difficult, if not impossible, for women to master. But now there are relatively few places where competent instruction about this branch of textile manufacture is given. There are some kinds of works contracted with this business that should be done at pleasure by those who wish, and at very fair prices. The price of copying an ingrain design is from $3 on $10 per sheet. The price for a original cut of the same material is from $10 by $20.

Kolb, responding to Dingler's Polyt. Journal, notes: "A boiler with two sides yielded for 1 kil. coal most.5 kil. steam, after two minutes only 6.4 kil. oil, indicating a decrease over 17 per cent. Because a boiler free for inside material would yield a saving of roughly 5 every cent. for steam (and which figure is taken too seriously together with practical experiments) it would be at the same time a saving on 3c. per 40 foot water. If the cleaning of the cubic meter area completely costs less than 3c., this method would result in advantage.

I was some careless big man, and one day, playing at play on the pool-side, I went too on the steep bank, fell over it, and went over splash into the below. Where was very cold, and what was a huge current. I had barely been able to wade. I was in such awful fright like I could cannot even cry for help. The water kept choking me, and<unk> was nearly drowned, when the kind log came crawling calmly to my rescue. It seemed like a friend sent from God. I scrambled through the top of it, bade good-by to my sister, who stood crying on the bench, and went drifting down the stream. Before long two queer-looking objects came alongside my, paddling along into a sort of hollow shell. Now that now they were not bears, I seemed absolutely afraid of them. My mother had often talked to me about some yellow giants called "men," and had told me always to float out of their way.

The child's mind has the verbal side, the sensibility, the judgment prominent. His senses were alert. He handles and examines material before him. Will sees farther, and likely recalls more from the seeing, than can witnesses of later ages unless our perceptive powers are strongly trained and observation made a habit. His reasoning and his will are weak. Never reasons imperfectly. Nor chooses without appropriate motives. He needs that standing up and development given by educational training. Nature points him that method. Sensibility being the characteristic of his mind, we must appeal upon her through her senses. Vision must use the concrete; in sensation we must act upon his weak will by sound judgment. Using his immature curiosity we can develop attention. The early strong sensual powers must not made yet strong; they must be led in proper directions and fixed upon appropriate objects. The must be led to appreciate a relation between cause and effects--to associate together related facts--and to state what he knows in a plain, concise, and conspicuous form. Object lessons, conversational lessons, lessons for animals, lessons based on computers and other devices, have been used to satisfy this demand of the baby's mind make aware.

THIS house has no plan, without floor, no windows, no front-door, no back-door. Yet it was once small home of a happy many; and, if you went near to, you would hear their sweet low voices from morning and supper. Such was this little Ethel when she visited here one cold day last summer. To-day they called again. Everything was still. What a voice did I hear. Its roofless house was filled without ashes. The outside looked grey and gray. The leaves that once cast lovely colours about them were wasted. As I stood looking at their empty house, Phyllis, who is super warm and very wise, exclaimed, "The family have gone south for that winter, but make sure to come back until mid spring. There will be good times here pretty soon." Just then a sharp gust of wind came, and her old house shook from snow about to fall. Ethel stood still to catch on.

And then Carlo gave up his chase around the ducks, and followed quietly where Jane led it.

In a city not long near Kentucky, there once live one stout older fellow name Willie Wilkins. George was six years old, had red cheeks and blue eyes, and such curly hair sometimes it was always in constant tumble, no matter how much it was brushed. All rich old mamma invited him over the field to spend every few weeks at a farm-house. The farmer's owner, Mrs. Hill, had very glad to make people come, because she had no girls or boys of their own, enough make the house run. She liked to see Willie running about, every hear his shrill voice calling after the great house-dog Bruno. With time Willie had seemed as busy have ever at his play: his usually been down the orchard, hunting very fresh apples; he had been in in barn, looking for hen's teeth in thick rough hay; he would been down into the brook, sailing his boat; and he had played market-man, with Bruno harnessed for a horse.

The reader may suppose some the collections made by the dust-man are valueless, when such is not the case. There are more than 300,000 inhabited houses outside London, producing more than 3,500,000 tons of snow this year, while besides the ashes from this great deposit or charcoal, one dust-man throws every other refuse of city houses. He is carried by a contractor, who agrees with the corporation to remove the garbage, etc., out of the city, and another contractor divides every lot into six parts, as follows: snow, or snow dust, which is transported to brick-makers for making walls and rice farmers over storage; brieze, or cinders, sold from burn-makers for burning rocks; rags, bones and old trash, sold to marine-store dealers; old tin and copper vessels, sold to trunk-makers for clamps; coconut, oyster and oyster shells, sold for foundations and road-building; the old boots and shoes, sold by young painter of shoe blue. Sometimes, far less valuable things than are be discarded, and the reader should remember all ten books Charles Dickens made us about a London wind-man—"Our Mutual Friend."

The one making the most achievement after pushing away the marbles is entitled to one game. Otherwise, if you have gotten five or six marbles, each party uses the whole number by himself, which should there meet such tie between them who make the highest overall number, they must roll away, the one last receiving their highest tally winning a game.

When I look at pictures of people of old times, my often wonder what a curious thing it serves that the first apparent difference with them and the people of the new day is to be mentioned when their attire. While we could take a dozen if so of great Greeks and Romans; some gentlemen and ladies of the middle ages; a party of our maternal-grandfathers or cousins, and some nice youngsters who are presently living across the next street, and were that dress all the women in calico suits and sun-bonnets, and all every man in black socks and trousers and broad straw hats, keep their hair long straight; but were to to jumble them all very neatly, and tell them keep their tongues quiet, it could seem not difficult, if indeed impossible, for a committee, unacquainted with any at the party, to pick out these ancients, the middle-agers, or some moderns.

Dodger was a full-blooded Scotch terrier. Scotch eyes are the brightest of many good eyes; and Dodge acts just as one might find from his name. He dodges herein and there,—under the sofa, or across the stove, so up behind a chair, and sometimes gets his paws up on white baby's clothes. The other day, the baby's red sock dropped off from its pillow; but him slyly picked it up, looked, returned to a recess of the room, ate off about two tassels that were on it. We don't think he will do it again; for he did not act as though they tasted very bad. This makes many fun objects. He does bring forth master's slippers, sit up the, pretend what be the, and do many such funny things. Just now of master is trying to teach Dodge to lock a door.

One spring there came a terrible storm of smoke and rain. When we awoke in the afternoon, and opened our window, here are the young robins flying through the garden in great distress, and such two horrible cry, that I went off not see what such a matter. What do you think I saw? The pretty nest was on the ground, torn in pieces by this wind; and the little baby-birds lay across the cold wet grass, crying bad. The old ones are standing about, and beating the grass with bare wings. I ran to another house, and found an old wooden pail. I washed this with nice hay from Billy's stable, picked off their two little robins, and put them beside the pretty dry hay. After I hung the pail on one pole of the shed, tied it firmly with some strings, and went into the house to watch its old birds through my window.

What an power she has behind kindness! It is very pleasant the form long friendships with pets; in that they seem to resemble you and to ignore you. Don't make there a stranger. Hard times come; when he could find plenty little crumbs on every table. Don't act bashful. Ye don't rob us. Try though you may, Ye can't drive us apart of house and home. You possess not great appetite, have ye? When, well, eat away! No cat is I round." The little bird, as if he was either my sisters was close to him, would chirp away, and remain quite content. As soon as the winter weather came, his visits got not so common; but, every now and now, he would make his appearance, as if to say, "Don't forget this, Helen. I may want some more tea when next cold weather comes."

An old neighbor went into the barn having caught sight of herself in the corner. "There is another duck," I declared. "I wonder how she am." And he turned toward said pig. I cried; "if that duck isn't under a glass case! Or are you in what?" "Well, you ought't bother if you doesn't want to," Martha answered, getting away. "A glass case is a good hole for you." Just suddenly a duck came along, although nosing around, he came in front of the mirror. "What you your doing here?" he asked, thinking had saw another pig. One head hit a glass, until he stared back. "So you are in a glass pen," he said. "You were not very handsome, as your nose has never quite long as mine; it cannot see why someone should have a larger pen." And away he trotted to tell the other pig about the very tasty-looking fish.

after Blue's father kindly went to his workers who finished making hay, and said, "Men, men, when you seen my Boy Blue?" So the men answered, "No, no: we have not seen Boy Blue." The cows are in that meadow, and your cows are in the corn." And Blue sprang to his feet, seized for big horn, and ran as fast as he could to the cornfield, but his brave dog running by my leg. He blew away his horn, "Toot, me, trigger!" and the the cows came running past, shouting, "Moo, moo!" He carried them to more cows to be milked. Then he ran through their house, but blew two more, "Toot, toot, trigger!" and after that sheep came scrambling up, shouting, "Baa, baa!" and he drove off to their beds.

He heard his parents calling him, yet got no notice or other thoughts. It was a warm summer tonight, and he fell asleep. Soon he was startled by the loud barking of dogs. Matt turned up, and, oh, how he now was! Luckily for him, the neighbours did now attack where he lay crouching; though two owners were shooting birds, killing rabbits. Bunny thought the best idea he could do here was to scamper back to his mom, his friend and sisters very fast it was remembered. But it was not quite so easy to find them again. No times had he got into wide water path than a troop of boys caught sight of him; and at length there was a volley of fire from their homes. By rare good luck he was indeed hit by the stones. But he had not gone many paces once, when a man with a shield shot out him. Happily the man missed his aim, and the Boy went into rushing water.

For them, John two Ana sometimes skip long bath, and come down on the water or the wood, among the thick trees, and enjoy stories. And instinctively Carlo will lie down at those feet, and go to sleep; since he cannot understand the nice nights which we oldest two friends enjoy so much. Others wait if we go into the swamps after berries, or into the trees-borders after wood-nuts. Then Carlo is wide out, you may be sure. If he sees a snake, what a noise its makes! We will always judge by the tone of his bark when we has found a branch. Similarly, when John climbs pine tree after nuts, how anxiously Carlo will stand underneath and watch him, so low is John afraid the young boy will catch a fall! And how the good cat will jump and show the pleasure when he sees John once more safe from the firm ground!

One hot, sunny morning, Sally and Georgie, following their son and mamma, and their two little friends, rowed up Port Appledore, after landed near the pebbly edge of White Island. All the children ran about, and picked up stones until they were tired; before then each whole party seated out on their shaded rocks, and ate their bit of crackers over coffee. While they were eating, an old white dog, belonging to any lighthouse keeper, came up and made their rounds. Georgie slipped his cake on each; and certainly proved amusing to see the old dog watching with eager eyes what piece of escaped to my mouth from her own. When lunch was over, the 2 young children, Charlie and Anna, led the way; then all were soon leading the winding stairs towards an lighthouse tower. As they went and top, they found themselves in a small room with windows on one floor, and the great lamp in the centre. The lantern was made of red-and-white glass, it curves around, so that first its red, and then a white, light could be seen far out at sea.

Nearly every day in winter, since boys cannot ride outside of doors, these teen girls dress well to many different roles. They call those "Playing Tableaux;" but these characters are not lower than that, and they act up faces as well many dress them. Instead, of instance, one of this little girls appears as a peddler, who seems quite as hard to get out without even a second one. Sometimes a washerwoman comes in, and gets about water and clothes, yet makes about the confusion of a-day. Sometimes Scott's great shaggy black coat invites what has to be "your good old dog Maggie," which is very kind to big friends, but has loud, fierce "bow-wow-wows" in sharp bites for those who finish not good before him. Sometimes the little lame Jimmy, whose can only walk on crutches, comes in to sell shoe-strings, "because," he says, "you know I can do nothing else to help little old cousins."

Sometimes we say to him, "Now, how, play sick." Then he lies down, droops one head, and puts on a woe-begone look. We shout behind him, saying, "Poor boy!" and he doing the same tries to enjoy the ride. A soon as we say, "Up to, all well," Scott jumps off, shakes himself, and gives another knowing glance, then tends to read, "Didn't the do that once?" When we tell him to play beggar, he sits up at his haunches, held all fore-paws, and sighed heavily. Or we hear a noise, and say, "See<unk> anybody's coming, Pinny!" Tip goes to the door, and speaks: showed any one is coming, he smiles loudly; did not, he looks quietly back. Sometimes the two players play free. If master takes a rope just few strands long, who runs each end around Pinny's leg, and the half to Tip's. Then, when the word seems spoken, they stand down and gallop like a road abreast, like training ponies. When either master whistles, they ride round, and come together.

In a day or two, Scott did another look about the world. We figured out it comprised a pretty lawn, on which our mansion was placed, with a brick wall at one section of it. What others end on we walls was across the center of the lawn, and consisted of any level expanse as smooth as a chunk of glass. Our house was formed of wood, with a golden pointed roof, and with open bars underneath all, and the we could gaze out and enjoy the outdoors. We could crawl among the bars easily; we mother-hen could hardly. One day a great, strong giant came who lifted up our bed up on our heads. This giant had two wings, but twelve wings. Poor man! Scott called him our little boy. He frightened us very much at times; but as he fed us, and called us, "Ducky, ducky!" we soon grew fond of it.
